text:
This is a great recipe. Based on my preferences and from previous feedback, I made some modifications. My husband and I like spicy food but I found this recipe as is is a little too spicy.  I only use a 1/2 of the jalapeños and cayenne pepper.   I use 2 cans of the green chilies. I wanted my chili a little thicker so I pureed one can of the white beans and only used 2 cups of chicken broth.  I also added a can of black beans and a can of corn.  And finally since the cheese adds a lot of fat, rather than mixing it all in, I just sprinkle a little on top before eating.  This is really delicious.  Everyone I serve it too raves about it.

text:
We loved this recipe but it is soooooo hot! Per a previous review, I cut down to 2 cans of beans, and only used 1/4 tsp of cayene pepper and added some sour cream to cool it down but still...HOT! I will make again but I will eliminate the jalapeno peppers altogether (I'm not a huge fan of them anyways), cut the cumin down to 1 tsp and omit all cayenne pepper. Really, the taste is fabulous...if your not weak of tongue. I was practically sweating just eating a bowl! Still, will make again with my alterations.

text:
First of all Excellent the tase is quite unique.  Two helpful hints.  I put everything together before I even turned on the flame on my big pot.  Also I put the cheese in last so that it would not burn on the bottom of the pot.  Made it both ways and frankly both ways turned out the same with the surprise when you eat it the next day.  WOW!

text:
I added a can of corn, used a can of cream of chicken in place of one can of chicken broth, used all mild green chilies instead of jalapenos (it came out perfectly spiced), and threw everything into the crockpot on high for 4 hours.  I hand-shredded the chicken at the end and put it back in.  Delicious!  Oh, and I also pureed one can of the white beans and that really helped to thicken things up.

text:
This chili is outstanding.  My husband isn't a big fan of chili, so I thought maybe a white chicken chili would interest him instead.  Ten bowls later, I can assure you he (and everyone else) loves it!  Serve with a dollop of sour cream and a scoop of salsa on top...it tastes great once it's stirred in.  But be careful if you don't like hot foods, or are serving to people who don't.  It is considerably hot (and this is coming from someone who eats jalapenos out of the jar, wasabi with a spoon, and puts cayenne pepper in her green bean casserole).  Cool it off with less jalapenos (replace with mild green chiles) if you need to.  I also like to serve this chili over a serving of rice (sounds strange, but it's really really good!).

text:
OH MY GOSH! This was great!!! I used skinless, boneless chicken tenders instead of the cooked chicken. I sauted them until they were no longer pink, then added the onions, fresh garlic, chiles, and spices to the same saute pan...Then I dumped everything into a big stew pot, and simmered it for an hour or so. I also added about 2 tsps of Chili Powder, and substituted shredded Colby/Jack cheese...This recipe got rave reviews from everyone! I served it with warm flour tortillas, and a huge salad. YUM! Will make this again!.

text:
This soup is nothing short of awesome. My husband raved about this soup for 2 days. I did brown the cooked chicken w/ the onions, didn't have white beans, just used 1 can navy beans & 1 can dark red kidney beans, added some frozen corn and 1 can of cream of chicken. Then, since it was EXTREMELY spicy (quite a kick) and sort of thin, I added some diced potatoes to absorb some of the broth and "kick". My husband was getting it out of the pot before I even added the cheese, which I'm sure is just as good sprinkled on top later.  This recipe really surprised me on how it tasted like something you would get @ a pricey restaurant. It smells really good when cooking and would be an awesome soup to serve @ a party (and impress your guests). Way to go!

text:
This is SO good!  I just made it and am waiting for my husband to get home; if he doesn't hurry, it will be too late.  :-)  We like hot spicey foods, but we don't like it so overpowering that the heat takes over the flavor.  SO!  I used only 2 tablespoons of the jalapenos and chopped them up very finely so they would be well-distributed throughout the dish.  I also used 1/4 tsp of cayenne pepper.  This is perfect seasoning for us.  I also only put in one can of chicken broth on the advice of other reviewers, and I added a 4th can of beans to thicken it up a bit.  Thank you, Cathy!  It is great!

text:
Yum!!  We loved this recipe.  Made some changes.  Used one pound all white meat ground turkey and 2 skinless, boned chicken breasts diced.  Cooked the meat together with the seasonings.  Added some chili powder to the seasoning.  Reduced the cayenne to 1/8 teaspoon.  To further lower fat I skipped the cheese and put 1/2 can beans in food processor and used this to thicken.  Garnishes on side to use as desired were: cheese, tortilla chips, sour cream, salsa and red onion.   Warms your tummy in this very chilly winter!

text:
I love this recipe! However, I make a few modifications.. #1, I throw everything into a crockpot (including the uncooked chicken) and let it all cook together.  #2. I puree the white beans before putting them into the mix.  This makes it much thicker and chili-like.  #3. Once the chicken is cooked I shred as opposed to chopping it.  I also don't use that much chicken broth - maybe a cup or a cup and a half.  It's a very thick and rich chili when it's all done - delicious!

text:
Wowzer...this was awesome, but HOT!  My 4 oz can of jalapeno peppers really packed a punch, but it was oh so yummy!  I only used 1 can of small white beans, which I pureed before adding to the pot.  It made the chili nice and thick.  I also used a whole block of pepper jack cheese, which I grated.  Next time I make this, I will use a rotisserie chicken (if I can remember to buy one) instead of the boiled chicken tenders I used. At the end, I threw in a handful of chopped cilantro and served the chili over crushed tortilla chips. This was excellent and I can't wait to make it again. Thanks a million.

I double the green chile peppers and leave out the jalapenos to make it kid friendly, and it's still plenty spicy. text:
everyone loved it.  used a costco chicken shredded (about 4 cups- no wings or legs).  too much chicken.  next time stick to 3 cups.  used about 1/4 of the jalapenos and perfect (served rest on side). served w/ crushed tortilla chips too- so yummy. left cheese on side and sour cream (added lots of sour cream to kids bowls to cool down the kick).  cooked on stove brought to a boil then put it in slow cooker on low for an hour and then kept it warm so it was ready when we got home.  i pureed 1 of the cans of navy beans but i bet  1 1/2 would be better- also used the blender/puree thing in the entire crock pot to make a tiny bit thicker.  depends on your preference.  served w/ bread and hot dogs.  yummy.  enough for 6 adults or 4-5 adults and a few kids.

text:
I just won a chili cookoff with this recipe, out of 12 entries!  I was a little short on time, so I did end up using a store-bought garlic and herb rotisserie chicken, which I shredded.  I also doubled the amount of green chiles, left out the jalapenos, added a small jar of salsa verde, and doubled the cumin so that it tasted more like chili than chicken soup.  I took someone else's advice and pureed one can of the beans for a thicker texture, swirled sour cream on top, and sprinkled chopped cilantro on top for a prettier presentation.  People were clamoring for the recipe, and I'm making another batch this week for the folks who weren't able to taste it before it was all eaten up.  My first chili cook-off win ever!

text:
I've made this twice now, and both times the pot has been licked clean! I use my crockpot on low and throw in raw chicken breasts with the chicken broth and diced onions ans let it cook for a couple hours. Then I add the seasoning and chilies and jalapenos and give it another couple hours. Then I hand shred the chx breasts and add 2 cans of white beans, 1 can of black beans and 1 can of corn. Another few hours in the crockpot and its ready! Sprinkle cheese and a dollop of sour cream and its amazing!!

text:
FANTASTIC!  I do have to agree, however, that we must call this what it is - soup.  But FANTASTIC SOUP!  The variations I made:

-Pureed one of the cans of white beans
-Added one can of Black Beans
-Added frozen corn
-Used only 1 Tbs Jalapenos
-Added extra can green chilis
-Added dollop of fat free sour cream to each bowl
-Omitted cheese in soup, but sprinkled some on top of each serving
-Used one whole rotisserie (sp?) chicken instead of cooking my own
-Used 1/2 called for cayene pepper
-After cooking onion, threw rest of ingredients in the crock pot on low for 6 hrs

Made MUCH more than 4 servings!  My crockpot was full.

This resulted in a yummy, yummy soup.  Spice mild enough for my 3 & 5 year olds.  Hubby and I added some extra jalapenos to each of our bowls to kick ours up a notch, but it was plenty good without it.  Served with cornbread - mmmm!  THANK YOU, THANK YOU, THANK YOU!

text:
I think the key to this recipe is to use shredded chicken instead of chopped.  Boil the chicken with the garlic (I doubled the garlic and onions), onions, jalapeños, green chiles, spices and broth until it's able to be shredded, then return to the broth and simmer on low for as long as possible.  Then add the beans (undrained) and the cheese.  It's absolutely delicious!  You should NOT radically alter the recipe.  

P.S.:  The perfect accompaniment to this recipe is Absolute Mexican Cornbread (http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Absolute-Mexican-Cornbread/Detail.aspx).

text:
I usually make my Mom's recipe for white chicken chili, but have always found it too much like a soup, rather than a chili.  Tried Cha Cha's last night and it was fantastic!  Maybe it's not quite as thick as chili, but it's really close.  I put in 2 1/2 cans of navy beans and then smashed up the other 1/2 can, which helped to thicken it.  Also, I used 2-3 teaspoons of the jalapenos and green chilis, rather than the amount called for.  In addition, rather than chicken broth, I used store-bought chicken stock.  I also cooked it for an hour, rather than the time called for.  When it was done, I spooned it in individual bowls and hubby and I added cheese and sour cream to our liking.  This was fantastic, only takes one pot to make, and will definitely be made again in our house!

This really is a fabulous recipe. If you are thinking it is too spicy, just omit the jalepenos. I add a cup or two more of chicken broth and I use different kinds of beans each time I make it. I love it with Black Eye Peas. We sprinkle green onions, cilantro, monterey jack cheese, crushed tortilla chips, guacamole, sour cream, and a lime wedge on top. SO INCREDIBLY GOOD! A real comfort food. This is almost just like the White Chili recipe from Beyond Parsley. A cookbook put out by the Junior League of Kansas.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fabulous, and much easier than my old recipe that started with dried beans.  I had grilled chicken breasts on hand, so I shredded 3 large ones up for this chili.  I also modified amounts of spicy stuff, as we are not terribly fond of very spicy food.  I used 4 ounces of “tamed” jalapeños, and only ¼ teaspoon of cayenne.  Before serving, I smashed some of the beans in the pot to thicken the chili a bit.   I also topped the chili with the jack cheese instead of stirring it in.  Additional toppers  were chopped avocado, thin sliced scallions and salsa verde.  If you don’t have salsa verde, just some cilantro would be great.  Tamed jalapeños are a jarred product from Mezzetta’s.  The jalapeño was developed by Texas A & M Univ., and they have greatly reduced the capsaicin in these peppers.  They have all the flavor of traditional jalapeños, with *much* less heat.  We absolutely love them.  My old white chili recipe has been replaced!
Review:

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Very simple. I'd never made white chili before, this is a good beginner recipe.  I added two chopped red peppers which I sauteed with the onion and garlic and used Bill Echols taco seasoning(minus the hot spices because the soup would be hot enough without adding more chili pepper. I've got two kids I'm feeding, too.) I also added a small bag of frozen corn from Tacoma Boys. It's warm here, so I put all the ingredients in the crockpot and let it cook away on low all day. I think that might have been a bad move, because the chili came out kind of soupy. Other than that, I thought the flavor of this was very good, though a little weak. Could use a little more taco seasoning. I made Mexican Sunset Bread to go with. NOTE: I read somewhere that if you mash up one can of your beans, you don't have to worry about it thickening up. That's what I did and it would have worked out great, had I not made it in the crockpot. The next day, I did end up adding another round of Bill Echols taco seasoning and fresh cilantro. That helped the flavor quite a bit.

Have made this twice -Would give this 5 stars but I tweek it so I can't give it five as it stands.  It is definitely on the hot side, I ease up on the peppers a bit and it is still plenty spicy. I like cumin, so I add a bit more. YUM! Now its ready for 5 stars!

text:
Brought it to the potluck.  And out of the 5 crockpots full of soup, this was the only one that disapeared, and disapeared quickly.  It was a hit.

Ok it was altered.  But still very close to the original.
no can of green chilis - I deseeded and put in 2 Anaheim chilis;
no jalepenos and no cayenne - 1 tsp of crushed red peppers; 
no chicken broth - 3 cubes of bullion, one cup water, one cup milk;
2 cans of white beans plus juice, not 3;
2 cups of moterey, not 1, dairy is what makes white chili, want healthy? then go eat red or green chili;
added 2 tblsp of lime juice;
added 1/4 cup of fresh cilantro

text:
I have made this recipe twice. The first time I followed the recipe without the green chilli peppers and about half of the spices. It was very good. The second time, I used left over turkey meat from Thanksgiving and followed the recipe exactly as printed. This was entirely too spicy for us (even my husband, who likes it very spicy). So I added the following: 1 large onion, 1 stalk celery, and 1 carrot (all diced), an extra can of chicken broth and 1 can of veggie broth. This helped to lighten the heat. I will make this again because the general recipe is very good. With a little improvising this can be adjusted to your preferences.

text:
I am going to buck the 5 star trend here.  I made this for the Superbowl; I cut the jalepenos by 1/2 based on other reviews. Even then, it was left mostly untouched by my guests. It was unpleasantly spicy. At the end of the game I had 15 bowls with one or two bites taken from it.  What a waste! So "as written" I give it a one or two star rating.  I would definately cut the cayenne, jalepenos and cumin by at least half, then add them back to taste later on.  I would also use more cheese and serve w/cheese on top. This can definately be a 5 star recipe, but as written, it will not get 5 stars from me.

text:
If you are like me, and prefer to save as much time as possible, cook this in your slow cooker.  I added all ingredients except cheese (used 3 large uncooked chicken breast) and cooked 8 hours on low - it came out fantastic.  I did use some other user's tips:  I cooked with 2 cans white beans, 1 can black beans, 1 can of corn, omitted the can of jalepenos and added a fork full of sliced jalepenos.  You can't mess this up in the slow cooker, it came out nice and thick.  I served with a dollop of sour cream and my husband added cheese and ate with tortilla chips.  So simple and came out great!  Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
This was a great recipe!  I love hot foods and this was definitely HOT.  It was a bit too hot for me, actually.  I added one more can of chicken broth, a bag of cheese, fresh jalapenos with out the seeds, a half teaspoon more cumin, one can of diced tomatoes , chili powder instead of oregano, and ground chicken instead of chopped.  I rinsed all of my beans and tomatoes really well.  The cheese and extra broth cut down on the spice quite a bit.  I think that using fresh seedless jalapenos instead of the canned may have cut down on the heat as well.  All in all, this was a very good recipe and easy to manipulate into your own style.

text:
I would have given this recipe 5 stars, except I made a few changes!  I agree with the other reviews that this was going to be super spicy so I changed it up a bit so the entire family would enjoy.  Instead of preparing it like the directions, I used the crockpot instead! I threw in 2 frozen chicken breasts (you can put in thaw uncooked chicken to speed up time), 1 can of corn (drained), 2 cans of white beans, 1 can of white kidney beans, 1 can (4oz.) green chiles, 1 can of chicken broth (I found it was too soupy with 2 cans of broth, but just my preference), half of an onion (diced), 3 cloves garlic (minced), 2 tsp cumin, 1 tsp cayenne pepper, 1 tsp oregano, salt/pepper to taste.  I put the crockpot on for 6 hours (high) and then shredded the chicken 30 mins before serving.  It was so delicious!!!  Certainly will be a regular at our house.

text:
Excellent, fairly easy dinner on a below 30 degree night!  To pre-cook the chicken, I brined & poached it in salted water with about 2 Tbsp. southwest seasoning.  I'm almost glad that I brined it, because the chili itself was a tad underseasoned.  I added a few tsps of salt to perk it up.  
Great heat level for my taste (I don't like too much) and the 4 of us finished off the pot for dinner with some corn bread.  Will be making this again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE this chili. I have made this recipe several times and finally found the perfect combination for my tastes. To begin, I cook and shred about a pound of chicken breast. I dice 1 medium onion and cook it along with 6 cloves of garlic. I omit the jalapeno peppers. I add two cans of green chilies. I use 2 tsp. of ground cumin, 2 tsp. of oregano, and 1/4 tsp. of ground red pepper (do not have cayenne pepper). I use 2 cans of chicken broth. I use 4 cans of white beans (puree 3 of the cans in the blender). I do not add the cheese to the mixture, but rather let everyone add what they would like on their own. It is excellent with crushed tortilla chips and sour cream on top as well!! This recipe is a KEEPER!!

text:
Right up my ally but I gave it only 4 stars since I had to make so many alterations to the recipe. Based on other reviewers suggestions, I omitted the jalapeno and only put about a pinch of the cayenne pepper in it. These are some other alterations I made to make this good dish an extraordinary dish: the juice of 2 limes, 2 tbsp chardonnay, little less than 1 tbsp balsamic vinegar, 1/2 tsp salt, 1/8 tsp ground black pepper, 1/4 tsp sugar, pinch red pepper flakes, and fresh cilantro. I also used just 2 cans of white beans and 1/2 cup frozen corn kernals (frozen for better freshness). I also cut a few corn tortillas into strips, brushed them lightly with oil, and baked them until very lightly browned for extra garnish and flavor. Delicious with these additions!

text:
I made this at my parent's house and we all loved it.  Heat-wise I found it to be mild and my parents thought it was just perfect.  When making it for myself I would probably add peppers much higher on the Scoville heat scale.  It had a great flavor anyway so for most people adding hotter peppers would be unnecessary.

If you want more of a chili I'd recommend swapping one can of broth with an extra can of beans.  Just mash beans on the side of the cooking pot to preference.  Don't forget that you'll be adding cheese at the end which will thicken it even more.

userID:

Display Name:
Lisa Stecher Brislane
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1680670.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this recipe 4 stars, although I don't make it exactly as written.  We never use canned beans, so I pre-soaked 1 lb. of dry white beans and cooked them with the other ingredients in the crock pot.  I did skip the jalapenos and only used a dash of cumin & cayenne, due to my family's preferences.  I think the crock pot cooking makes all the difference in the world, because it gives the flavors more of a chance to combine, which reduces the "bland" flavor some have complained about.  It also soaks up much of the liquid, and after removing & pureeing some of the beans just before serving, it ended up with the perfect texture.  The initial recipe is great for a quick meal, but the crock pot makes it so much better.  (I cooked it for 7 hours on high.)

text:
Loved this ! I used no sodium broth so I could adjust the salt as needed. I also used a can of corn in place of one of the cans of beans. Always rinse and drain your canned veggies very well before using. I had a fresh jalapeno ,so I used half of a medium sized jalapeno, chopped fine.You definitely want to adjust the heat factor to your liking as this can get really hot ! I started out with half the cayenne and less than half jalapeno. I used a dollop of sour cream instead of cheese and added tortilla chips when serving. My boyfriend took this to work and all the guys loved it !

text:
First time making a chicken chili. This is really good, made a few changes based on review and families dislike of a lot of heat. I used 2 cans of green chili's and just a dash of cayenne, omitted the jalapeño. I added 1 teaspoon of flour when I sautéed onions and garlic. I smashed 1 of the cans of beans to help with thickness, someone did mention it was a bit to thin for chili. It worked out fine, was the perfect texture and thickness. Really good flavor, will def. make again.

text:
I make a big pot of this twice a month.  We all love it!  I think the heat is just right. I've begun adding a couple cans of garbanzo beans for their texture (navy beans are so soft, garbanzos keep a little chew) .  I use fresh jalapeños when I think of it, which adds a nicer flavor then the canned.  Other than that I make it pretty straight from the recipe.  Healthy, fast, delicious and tastes even better over the next few days when I bring it to work for lunch.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty good as written, but I had to adjust the spice level for our tastes by reducing to cayenne to about 1/3 tsp, and I also only used the one can of jalapenos as I didn't have chilis on hand.  I wanted to make this to reheat later in the week, so I omitted the Monterey Jack as I wasn't sure how that would reheat, plus now I can top with either the jack, queso blanco or even just plain sour cream at each serving.  I also omitted the parsley and subbed fresh cilantro which I added in the last five minutes of cooking, and I didn't used canned beans, but rather soaked and cooked my own great northern beans the day before, and used homemade no salt added chicken broth, so I did add a bit of salt for flavor to the finished product.   I think next time I'dd like to add some sort of vegetable, corn, carrots or zucchini, and I think using boneless, skinless chicken thighs instead of or in addition to the chicken breast would give this a bit more flavor, but all in all, I liked this!

text:
My husband and I get together with close friends every weekend and I've made this for our dinner twice. It is the best white chicken chili I've ever made, hands down. I only made 2 changes to the recipe: I use Caldo con Sabor de Pollo for the broth which eliminates the need for additional salt and I leave the jalapeno peppers out because not everyone likes the heat. To make up for it, I had a healthy dash or three of Crystal hot sauce.  If you're looking for a tasty white chili recipe, this one is it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Can't give it 5 stars because I did alter it a little...
I cooked the chicken and then added the onion because I didn't have any precooked chicken.  I used 2 fresh jalapenos instead of canned.  I used 1/2 tsp of cayenne and replaced the other 1/2 tsp with regular chili powder.  I only used 1 can of low-sodium chicken broth because I didn't want my chili soupy.  Last but not least I used only 1/3 of a cup of Pepper Jack Cheese, instead of an entire cup, to lower the fat content a little and well, quite frankly that is all I had.  I topped with a tsp of light sour cream and a pinch of minced cilantro.
This was still quite spicy but not overwhelmingly so.  My kids complained about this being what I was making for dinner, however both went back for more.  Easy & Tasty!

A lovely white chicken chili. Based on others' comments, I only added about 1/3 -1/2 of the broth to make it less soupy. A few comments: the jalapeno bite was very nice but the flavor behind it didn't offer as much depth as I like in my chili. The added cheese and cilantro (both as garnish) helped but it was still one dimensional.  I made this and the "meatiest vegetarian chili" for a crowd and the flavors in my vegan option beat this chili hands down. A nice alternative, but not a blue ribbon option.

text:
Wonderful white CHILI, not soup, if you make a few changes: used 1/2 lg. onion, 1 can 30% less sodium chicken broth, 1 bottle beer (Bells Winter White today), no jalapenos (didn't have any), meat of one rotisserie chicken with skin removed (too salty otherwise), puree one of the cans of beans.  Other ingredients not listed were the same.  Near end I added about 4 oz. low fat cream cheese and about 4 oz. low fat sour cream.  Served with a dallop of sour cream, cheddar cheese, and Fritos.  Excellent!

userID:
2499516
Display Name:
mamamilkies
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
30
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the whole thing from scratch so I could control the sodium. I made the chicken stock and then de-boned the chicken and used that for the chili. I also used dry beans instead of canned. I'm not a big fan of the jalepenos, so I used just one can of the green chilis. I was also out of cumin and cayenne so I improvised with a dash of chili powder and some cinnamon (hey, I was desperate!) and the oregano. I also used 8 cups of chicken stock and twice the amount of beans and chicken. The overall result is mild enough that my three small children gobbled it up and yummy enough that I really enjoyed it! I think I would like it a thicker "chili" type consistency so next time I will try the previous suggestion of pureeing several cups and I also cut back on my chicken stock. I served it with homemade cornbread and it was a HUGE hit! What a delicious, VERSATILE recipe!

Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

This is one of our favorite chili recipes! My boyfriend and I like our food spicy so we throw in 2 cans of jalapenos and omit the green chilies since I'm not a big fan. I also about 2/3cup of corn and 1/2 cup more cheese. It's a staple in our recipe list!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Here's an endorsement if ever there was one.  After ooh-ing and ah-ing over his first few bites, my husband said he would stand in line and take abuse from the soup nazi for this.  I changed it up a bit which helped with the "ugly" factor that some reviewers mentioned.  I sauteed cubed raw chicken breast in olive oil and then added the onions, etc.  Because I had them on hand, I also used chopped celery, red, green and orange bell pepper in addition to the canned chilies.  I used fresh jalepeno rather than canned.  I had half a can of diced tomatoes left from a meal this week so dumped those in.  I also started with dry beans and soaked and cooked them myself rather than using canned, so I left some of the liquid on the beans and added chicken base paste rather than using the canned broth.  At serving, I followed someone's suggestion and crushed some tortilla chips in the bottom of the bowl, used cheddar and jack cheese to garnish,along with a dollop of sour cream and just a few sprinkles of fresh chopped cilantro.  We loved it and will certainly make again.  It wasn't ugly at all by the time i was finished with the make-over.

text:
This recipe rocks.  I have made it several times.  The only thing I do different is puree 1 1/2 cans beans and leave the other 1 1/2 cans whole.  It makes it nice and thick.  Also, I don't mix the cheese in...I just sprinkle some on top at the end.  Other than that it is a great recipe...just adjust the hot peppers to taste.  Remember you can always add more, but you can't take them away.

text:
This chili is awesome. The recipe makes much more than four servings. I had a whole crockpot full.

To get a more white chili, I slowly added about a 1/2 to 3/4 cup of ranch dressing to the mix once it was simmering. I also added a little bacon bits.

Also, take one of those 15 onunce cans of white beans and mash it up into a paste. This help thicken the chili.

text:
Unbelievable flavor for so little effort.  Per other suggestions, I mashed 1 can of beans with a fork; I left out all the hot stuff, subbed 3/4 of a large jalapeno, sliced very thinly, fried up with the onion, and 1/4 tsp red pepper flakes.  Added one small can salsa verde. Used 2 cups water and 2 bouillon cubes in place of broth.  Used a precooked store bought chicken.  Wonderful recipe, very very quick and so delicious we were amazed!  Thanks!

text:
Very good!  I did this in the crock pot and cooked on for several hours.  I left the lid off for the last hour trying to thicken it up.  I had tried just pureeing one can of beans like everyone said, but still thought it was too soupy.  We like more solids than broth.  I ended up putting in a fouth can of beans to make it thick enough to suit.  I also left out the jap's entirely and it's mild enough for even our light-weight pallets.  Will definately make this again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this 10 years, since I first found it on AllRecipes.com. Buy a pre-cooked roaster chicken (I like BBQ or Sam's Club flavors), remove the meat, rough chop and set aside 'til needed, then cover bones, skin, etc. in water and create broth from it while you're cooking the onion mixture. The seasonings from the roaster chicken give it an added depth of flavor. Fill a discarded bean can with the broth (it's 14.5 oz) twice and add to your mixture. Also, I only use 2 oz jalepenos, and double up on the cheese. Enjoy!

text:
YUM!!  I am kind of wimpy when it comes to spicy food, but I was making this for my boyfriend who loves, LOVES spicy food. He likes to turn red and break a sweat when he eats (very weird). So I used the full amount of cayenne, but I used chopped FRESH jalapeños. I must be missing something when everyone says it's so hot. I didn't think it was even the slightest bit spicy. Maybe is was because of the fresh jalapeños. So I added more cayenne and still didn't think it was hot. I broke out a jar of jalapeño slices and put about 1/4 cup in the food processor and chopped them up. It's perfect for me, but I know it won't be spicy enough for him. But it's sooo super good.  I also puréed some of the beans and that was a great idea, thanks to all that recommended it. I made naan to eat it with. I'm so pleased with myself!  :-)  this stuff is awesome. I must be building up a tolerance to spicy food though. Great recipe. Oh, and yes.. The longer it sits, the better it is. All the flavors really combine.

text:
The author of the recipe states it is pretty spicy and if you want a milder version cut back on the jalapenos.  A teaspoon of cayenne is quite a bit.  I reduced the cayenne and increased the green chilies with excellent results.  The flavor was more like a Navajo-style green chili stew made with chicken instead of pork.  On a second batch substituted chicken thighs for the breast with excellent results.

userID:
13909686
Display Name:
Nougat
isPro:

followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is so good! The reviews are right, this is quite spicy! I followed the recipe almost exactly with only a couple of changes. I used my own home made chicken broth, I minced the garlic, and I didn't have canned jalapenos, so I diced up a fresh one, ribs, seeds, and all. I only used two cans of white northern beans, and I took a potato masher to them to give a little thickness to the chili. I have to say that I didn't cook the onions or anything else first. I just took all the ingredients and put them in the crock pot. It's been so warm here that I didn't want to even turn on the stove. I just took the crock pot to a downstairs room, plugged it in, set it to low and closed the door. Six hours later, supper time, and it was done! I used rotisserie chicken breast and I left out the cheese. It was just awesome! Spicy and so full of flavor I don't think there was room for any more! This would be great, even without the chicken! I think it might have something to do with the absence of chili powder, honestly I don't think it needs it, and would probably not help at all. Cilantro might be good in this though, and maybe sour cream for cutting the heat, if that's the way you roll. This is the best chicken chili recipe I've ever used! Thank you!

text:
I add extra broth, extra chicken, extra cheese and sub 1 can of green jalapenos for red jalapenos.  I also add one small bag of frozen corn, 2 roasted red peppers (from jar and diced) and a dash of cinnamon to give it a hint of sweet before the heat.  I mix it all together and simmer for an hour (except for the cheese) and then refrigerate for at least 1 day to let the peppers marinate throughout.

text:
This won my neighborhood's chili cookoff.  Here are my shortcuts:  Buy Perdue Chicken "Shortcuts" in Southwest flavor--dice and use.  In addition to the 3 cans of beans, add another can of white beans but pureed--adds great thickness.  I always throw in a little extra cumin too.  Great for a football game or a healthy lunch, best recipe on this site!!!

Wow.  This is amazing.  I had about 1/2 of a cooked oven stuffer roaster that I was looking to repurpose.  I tried to stay true to the recipe but though I LOVE spicy food, I toned it down a bit for my family by leaving out the jalapeños and just using canned chilis.  I always try to sneak more veggies in so when i turned off the stove, i stirred in the zucchini and let it stand covered for about 15 minutes. i need to avoid dairy so i didnt stir the cheese in but rather topped the bowls with Colby jack.   as i was making it, i was tasting and thought it was really good.  i tasted after adding the cheese and the cheese takes it from great to completely amazing.  i will be making this again - CHA CHA CHA!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Simple, spicy, delicious. 

No need to add salt (broth, beans, cheese provide enough). Two cans beans is plenty, so is 1/4 teaspoon cayenne. Used white onion for a Mexican touch. Simmered two chicken breasts in broth with a few chunks of onion before chopping chicken and to remaining ingredients along with the broth the breasts had simmered in. 

Added 1 heaping T masa harina before last 15 minutes of cooking to lightly thicken the sauce. Stirred in 3 T chopped fresh cilantro just before serving. 

Instead of mixing in the cheese, topped individual bowls with 1/4 cup cheese and a few tortilla chips for texture. Served with cold Corona and lime. My husband loved it. So did I.

text:
We loved this recipe! It was so easy to make and definitely will make again. I did do some of the recommended changes. I cooked the chicken breasts in a pan with ranch dressing packets. I used one 7 oz green chilis and didn't use the jalapeños since my family doesn't like things too hot.  I used low sodium broth and a can of cream of chicken. I  put in a can or two of tomatoes with mild green chillis.  I did grind up one can of beans to make a little thicker. I  added one can of hominy too for a little added flavor and a can of corn too. I let it simmer for a few hours and then I  topped the chili with a little bit of cheese on top of each bowl.  Everyone LOVED it!!
Mexican corm bread was a good addition to the meal too. Thanks!

userID:
6931040
Display Name:
Mary Porter Green
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1699692.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an outstanding recipe.  Healthy, easy to make, and tastes great.  I've made it a zillion times, and have found the following modifications to be helpful:  I use two cans of diced green chilis and skip the jalapenos.  I also use 1 tsp. of chili powder instead of the cayenne.  It still has a kick with these changes, and you can always turn up the heat in each bowl with Tabasco.  I add the chicken broth last and only add as much as necessary to get a good, thick consistency.  Assuming you don't drain your beans, using all the broth will result in chili that is more like soup (unless you boil it down).  I brown the chicken (using ample salt, pepper and oregano to flavor) and saute the onion/spices separately, then throw everything together into the crock pot and let it simmer for a long time.  I often add chunks of sausage to change up the flavor and texture.  I do not add the cheese, but rather sprinkle a little on top before serving.  To improve the presentation (it can look a little like gruel), I serve with cheddar cheese, sour cream, chopped cilantro and sometimes a bit of chopped red bell pepper.  Yum! A definite crowd pleaser.

text:
I love this chili! I've been making it with this recipe for years, and I don't change much.  If you're feeding people who don't handle spice well, skip the jalapenos and use a double sized can of chiles. I also shred the chicken instead of cubing it.  It's a more pleasant texture, even if it does take a little bit longer.  Making it for a dinner and board game party tonight. Mmm...

text:
Fantastic! The other reviewers are right... this stuff is spicy! But that is exactly how we like our chili. The chicken broth I used was very low sodium and organic. I love that this recipe doesn't call for salt, and it doesn't need it! I like a thicker chili so I cut down on the broth and added a tsp of corn starch to thicken it up. I also used two fresh jalapenos instead of the canned chilies. I think that it's the cayenne that makes this dish so wonderfully spicy! I also added a can of Rotel tomatoes and a can of regular diced tomatoes. For the beans I used cannellini, Great Northern, and pinto. I added some chopped cilantro at the end. I will definitely make this again! Thank you for sharing!

text:
I have been forever using McCormick white chicken chili seasoning packet, now I don't have to! This is a real good recipe! After reading other reviews about how spicy it is, I used two cans of chopped green chilies, not diced jalapeno peppers at all. I used 2 full sized chicken breast, diced then sauteed. I used only 2 cans of white beans. I made me own low-sodium chicken broth (approx 3-1/2 cups), I rinsed and drained the beans to try to remove as much of sodium. I added 2 tablespoons of masa harina to thicken it. This is really good!

text:
I had leftover chicken to use and leftover navy beans in the freezer, so I looked for something using those ingredients and came across this...loved it!  While this is not a kid-friendly meal, for my family (the 4-year old didn't like the way it looked and therefore wouldn't touch it), the adults in my life raved about it.  The only real change I made was to add green peppers, onions & omit the jalapeno peppers & chile peppers...I'm a fan of allowing others to determine their heat level.  I added minimal red pepper and for many that was just enough.  I will make this for pot lucks and/or for myself when the kids are away.  Thanks!

text:
We weren’t as thrilled with this as I had hoped.  And as written this is more like chicken and bean soup, not like any chili I'm familiar with.  I took some ideas from other reviewers and used two cans of diced chiles, no jalapenos and I cut back on the cayenne pepper.  My biggest regret was that I pureed one can of the beans to help thicken this up, but that gave the chili a gluey taste/texture.  I should have made a roux with flour and butter and added that to the chili to thicken it.  Oh well, maybe next time.

Dellicious!  I made a few subtle substitutions.  I used one can of cannnellini beans and pureed them to thicken the broth, and as previous reviewers suggested, halved the amount of jalapenos.  I also cut back a bit on the amount of cayenne pepper, and  amount of oregano to just over 1/2 teaspoon.  I purchased a grocery store rotisserie chicken, and cook time was a snap!  This recipe is delicious, versitle, and budget friendly.   A keeeper at my house!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/736695.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My first attempt at this recipe was good but not great. I shredded the meat on a rotisserie chicken from my local grocery store instead of cooking my own. I use this for my chicken tortilla soup as well because it has a fantastic texture and melts in your mouth not to mention, it's a huge time saver. I heeded the warnings about the spice and used half the can of jalapeños and 1/4 tsp of cayenne. Next time I'll definitely kick the spice back up because the flavor fell a little flat and the chili was extremely mild. I drained all of the ingredients so that it wouldn't turn out muddy looking. I also took the advice of others and pureed 1/2 of a can of the beans to thicken the chili. I'm still on the fence about whether or not I like the texture with the pureed beans. One last addition was a can of super sweet white corn which I enjoyed. I couldn't taste the cheese melted in the soup and it didn't seem to affect the texture so instead I would suggest just adding a bit on top for more flavor and less fat.

used 2 pounds of ground turkey instead of the cubed chicken. doubled the recipe, and ended up using only 4-5 cans of beans instead of 6. also, i used fresh chiles and jalapenos. i then added more chiles a half hour before it was done cooking, as letting it simmer for 2-3 hours took most of the heat out of the peppers. simmering also allowed it to thicken a little. it was spicy, but that's the way i like it. will definitely make again when i want a different taste in chili.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like most reviewers, I changed this for our tastes and mix it up each time I make this.  This time I used no oil but PAM, no garlic, one very large white onion, and an extra can of beans, which I pureed before adding. Tasted the canned jalepanos and found them to be super spicy (unusually so), so only added half of a heaping teaspoon of cayenne when I normally use the full amount.  Roasted 2 large bone-in chicken breasts with only salt and pepper and used that shredded which really brought the chili together.  Used a mixed blend of Mexican cheeses at the end and about a bean can full of water since I thought the chili was too thick.  Great recipe and one that is very easy to modify based on your family's tastes.

text:
i made this 3 times already! i would have given 5 stars, except for the first time i followed it exactly as written, and it was rather spicy, and a little too thin and brothy for me. so i changed it the next 2 times, and omitted the cans of broth, and changed it to a cup of water with 2 chicken bullion cubes. i also cut down the jalepenos by 75% and got rid of the cayenne, so it wasnt too spicy for me. i also added a little paprika and some salt. i topped it with shredded white cheddar, and it was so good that it made me wanna slap my momma!

text:
This was so easy and delicous not to mention relatively low fat!  I made a few revisions  - I used a rotisserie chicken and shredded the meat, two cans of white beans and one cup of Trader Joe's frozen roasted corn, two cans of chilis and no jalepenos as I didn't want it too spicy.  I left out the cayanne pepper as well but added a few shakes of chili powder.  I also made a fat free crema to dollop on top - one small container of plain fat free greek yogurt, juice of 1/2 lime, a few sprinkles of cumin and chopped fresh cilantro.  So good! I will be making this a lot in the cold months.

text:
What a great change up from the "norm". This chili was tasty, filling, easy/quick to make and relatively cheap...and when served with crackers (yes, crackers...they don't like cornbread!), went over great with my young children.   I omitted the jalapenos and just added green chiles - this was still PLENTY spicy for a younger crowd. I also only added one teaspoon of cumin, as I thought two would be overwhelming for that small of a batch of chili and I'm SO glad I did. The only other change I made was that I used a pre-shredded "mexican blend" cheese instead of just Monterey Jack. We'll be making this one again!

Made this with leftover turkey from thanksgiving.  For the beans, I used two cans, one white kidney beans or northern and one can navy beans with bacon. Made some adjustments based on other reviewers comments.  Used half Texas onion half green onion, 1 fresh jalepeno, and substituted chili powder and red flakes because I was out of cayenne.    Served with cornbread, a salad, and an option of toppings for the chili (fresh scallion, diced fresh jalepeno, chopped fresh cilantro, and shredded coley cheddar cheese mix)

It was a nice change to our weekly line-up, but I will continue to try to improve a white chicken chili. The boyfriend and I decided we both prefer the traditional tomato based chili, but this is not a bad recipe to try. I made the following alterations: one fresh jalapeno instead of canned, less cayenne pepper. To make the chili a bit creamier I added a half cup of milk after I removed the chili from the heat. I served topped with sour cream, freshly chopped tomatoes, and fresh cilantro.

country:
None
text:
The best "white" chili I have had!! I almost never change a recipe before I rate it, but others saying it was thin got me a little nervous. So I only made one change. Since I always make my own chicken stock from granules, I simply added only 23 oz of water and 3 tsp of granules. I thought this worked very well. I like the heat of the dish but can see how some would not.... I would not recommend changing the peppers in the recipe at all as they give a lot of depth to the flavor. If you want it milder, I would suggest dropping the cayenne instead of the peppers (you can always add a sprinkle to individual bowels later if you have a mixed crowd). As many have said: you can also top with a dollop of sour cream to cool it down which is very good.

text:
Edit 1-29-17: Made this again today and wanted to add a few comments. As written, the sodium is perfectly balanced imo. All I had today was low sodium chicken broth, so I had to add a bit of salt after tasting. Still delicious but not quite the same so I won't do that again. Also after reading other reviews, I added extra green chilis because we love them, but didn't notice my cans were 7 oz,  so added 14 oz total. Next time I will stick to 7 oz max, as I think this change slightly upset the wonderful balance of flavors that I love in this recipe. I still use the changes from my original review so I will stick to only those for the next time. Still this is a fabulous recipe if you like chili and so flavorful. 
---------------------------------------------------

I have made this often, and I think I prefer it to "regular" chili. I use jalapenos from a jar, only 1/2 t cayenne, and add 1 T chili powder and 1/2 t coriander for even more flavor. I don't find it to spicy at all. I also cook my own chicken rather than using canned. It's a bit soupy as I leave out the cheese, and serve it on the side along with sour cream, avocado, and tortilla chips. Definitely a 5 star, delicious recipe!!!

userID:
2261639
Display Name:
Tricia P.
isPro:
False
followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i have made this recipe as-written 6-7 times and it's one of those that comes out fantastically every single time. i prefer spicy food and the 1 tsp of cayenne pepper is *almost* too much heat.  in the sake of saving time and making more servings (4 servings doesn't last long in this house!), i've made the following modifications to approximately double the recipe and save time:  1-onion 3-cloves of garlic, crushed 2-10 oz cans Ro*tel tomatoes and green chilies with the juice (use mild if you like less heat) - omit the canned jalapenos & green chile peppers 1-15 oz can of corn double the amount of cumin (4 tsp) & oregano (2 tsp) 1/2 teaspoon cayene (omit the cayenne unless you like this REALLY spicy) 3-15 oz cans of white or cannelini beans, rinsed and drained 32 oz of chicken broth 1-rotisserie chicken, skin discarded and meat shredded 1-8 oz package mexican blend cheese (~2 cups)  after cooking the onion and garlic in the bottom of a large stockpot, add all the canned ingredients, spices, broth and shredded chicken. add 2 cups shredded mexican blend cheese to entire pot and stir thoroughly prior to serving.   i love this recipe because it's done  30 minutes -- and it tastes fantastic! there's also only one pot for the husband to clean.

Display Name:
Starlet

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did it in the slow cooker with 1 can of white beans subbed out for a can of mixed pinto, kidney and black. Put 2 frozen chicken breasts in, came back after 4 hours on low and cubed them and then returned the chicken to the crock and cranked it up to high for another hour or so. Also added about 1 cup of frozen corn for the last hour. It came out really good, but I would call it more of a soup than a chili. Maybe because I used an organic cream of chicken soup which is a little thinner than the icky red label kind. I ended up thickening it some with a roux and it resembled a white chili more after that. Good flavor as written, but I added a little seasoned salt and also a ts chili powder (it's not chili without chili powder!). I used fresh jalapenos rather than canned. Served it with a dallop of sour cream, fresh chopped parsley and we crunched up tortilla chips on top.  I've been sick, and this stuff with a whole lot of tabasco is the only reason why I can actually breathe right now!

text:
Great recipe! I decided to make this recipe today because I had all the ingredients handy, except for the green chilies.  I reduced the cayenne powder by half and added a little chili powder for the taste and color.  I started out by sautéing the onion and garlic and then added fresh cubed chicken.  Once the chicken was done I place it in a crock pot with the rest of the ingredients (except for the cheese).  The chili cooked for about 3 hours and when I was ready to serve I added the cheese and topped each individual bowl with low fat sour cream. My husband (who hates soup) really loved this recipe and said it was a keeper!

I left out the jalapenos and cut back on the cayenne as one user suggested and even then holy mother loving spicy!!!  I figure it must have been the brand of the roasted green chiles I used, because wow, spicy!  I ended up plopping in a few spoonfuls of reduced fat sour cream and then about 4 TBS of reduced fat cream cheese to cool it off, that helped a ton, but still incredibly spicy!  However, EXCELLENT flavor! If you like spicy, this is the dish for you!

text:
Tried 2 times & not going to waste time trying anymore. The 1st time I made as written, but didn't like white beans & it was overpowering from the heat of the cayenne pepper & jalapeno. Last night I used different beans which worked, didn't use cayenne pepper & seeded jalapeno pepper & it was still to hot. We added sour cream so we could eat it. We like flavorful food, spicy is great, but we like it where one ingredient (jalapeno or cayenne if using) doesn't overpower everything else. We felt that the jalapeno did just that - you couldn't distinguish anything. We'll stick with regular chili or a chicken taco soup from now on. Very disappointed.

I can't really review this recipe because I made changes and it wouldn't be fair either way to review a recipe I didn't follow. I just wanted to thank you for the great jumping off point. I used what I had on hand, chicken breast tenders, great northern beans and chicken broth. text:
Great alternative to regular chili!  I wish there was a 4.5 star rating.  I love this recipe and so does my husband, but I have to tweak it a little to get it right for us.  I've made this many times over the last couple years and the first couple of times, it was way too spicy, but we liked it enough to try it again (and again).  I use fresh instead of canned jalapenos (one or two, depending on size) and take out the membranes and most of the seeds when I mince it up.  I also cut back on the cayenne pepper - using about 1/2 tsp (maybe a little more).  And I don't like to stir in the cheese (other reviewers' advice too) in the pot, but let each person put some on top.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
after reading many reviews, I made the following changes for texture and spice:

- boiled 2 bone-in chicken breasts with red pepper flakes and cummin then shreaded the night before
-substituted 3/4 cup of half & half for 3/4 cup chicken broth (creamier texture)
-blended then added an additional can of beans (thickness)
-did NOT rinse beans and included syrup from can (also helped with thickness)
-substituted 2/3 of a fresh jalepeno
-omitted cayenne pepper (between the red pepper flakes in the chicken and the jalepeno, this was just slightly hotter than mild)
-ganished with additional cheese and about 1/4 cup of fresh chopped cilantro

It was a big hit and definitely one worth making again!

text:
Wow! Yeah, spicy. But my hubby & I love spicy. We both prefer the texture of shredded chicken in soups, so I put the chicken in the soup pot with 2 quarts of water and a dash of salt, dash of cayenne, and dash of cumin, and let it simmer at medium for an hour. Then I pull it apart. Set the chicken aside, discard the cooking water (not as flavorful as the chicken stock will be) and follow the recipe from there.

text:
Yummy, good comfort food on a cold day. I was scared of the spice that some reviewers complained about, so I cut out the jalepenos and doubled up on the green chiles. Next time, I will use the jalepenos. It seemed that it was missing something so I added ground coriander, chili powder and a couple of dashes of Tabasco. I also used a whole rotisserie chicken, shredded, per other reviews.  Next time I will definitely use cubed breasts. The rotisserie made it too salty and it just fell apart into tiny strings, making the chili look a little like mush soup. It is tasty though.

text:
Great recipe!! Ready in 30 minutes! I boiled chicken tenders for the cooked chicken it calls for. Made the recipe as written except I added a little extra chicken stock and a little bit of milk to take away some of the kick. The milk also gave it more of a creamy look. Stirred  sour cream and cheese into individual bowls, not the whole pot like it calls for. Also added avocado, cilantro, and lime juice to the bowls. It was so yummy and my Fiance said we needed to put this recipe in the "Make Again" pile. :-) Served it with cornbread muffins.

I gave this 4 stars only because I did make a few changes like a few other reviews suggested.  I pureed one full can of the beans, obmitted the jalapeno, upped the green chile to 7oz and instead of cayenne pepper I added only 1/2 tsp of chili powder (because that's what I had on hand).

text:
Extremely hot!  I did half the cumin, half the chile pwd and 1/2 tsp of jalapenos and it was still quite hot.

I cooked the chicken in 1 qt of water along with 1/2 a diced onion, salt, and diced carrots and celery and shredded it when fully cooked.  I then used the liquid in place of the chicken broth and onion in the recipe.  I dumped everything into a slow cooker and let it cook on slow all day.  Wonderful!!

text:
I just made this recipe and I love it. I, like a few others, made a few modifications. To solve the thickness problem I made a roux of 2 tablespoons butter and 2 tablespoons flour and added it with the broth. I also only added 2 cans of white beans and shredded the chicken by hand for a more homestyle effect. I served it with tortilla chips, which were very good crumbled on top. I will be making this again!!!! Thanks.

Oh man, sooo good! I used leftovers from a roasted chicken I made last night... my boyfriend and I both loved this recipe! All the reviews about how spicy it was scared me, (my tongue is not very brave!), so I scaled it down to 1/4 tsp. of cayenne and only about 1/2 the can of jalapenos... gotta say, I could have gone a lot spicer! Next time I will use all the jalapenos, and some more cayenne. I put in about 1/4 cup more cheese, let it simmer for about 20 minutes, and served it with some cut up avocado... yum! text:
Great recipe!  I made some minor changes, and it turned out superb!  First off, I added some diced celery to the onion, and substituted some Tabasco for the cayenne ( I was out of cayenne).  I used homemade chicken stock and added a can of low-fat cream of chicken soup while the mixture simmered.  It toned down some of the spiciness, I thought.  I only had 2 cans of beans, so that's what I used.  Thanks for the recipe!  It's a keeper!

This stuff is awesome!But if you're looking for something that tastes like beef chili this is not for you. We also garnished with a Monterey Jack/Cheddar cheese mix and sour cream. Delicious! Will definitely make again.

text:
Wow!  Spicy!  This definitely needs the cheese to temper the heat.  I used leftovers from a Costco rotisserie chicken, and only 2 cans of beans.  I also added cubed chayote squash as a variation.  It was very good.  I didn't mix the cheese into the chili, but rather served it on the side for sprinkling.  This was a definite hit and a keeper...
 ..........*note - just made this again last night, 1 can drained beans, 1 can ortega chiles, 1 can DICED TOMATOES (really added flavor!), frozen corn, chicken, onion, garlic, 1/2 can chicken broth.  It turned out really flavorful.  The tomatoes mean that it's not "white" chili anymore, but it was great!

text:
This chili is awesome!  I have brought it to a few school functions and earn rave reviews everytime.  My modifications are: adding an additional can of chilies and sauteing long enough to get the heat into the chili, I also add the jalapenos in the last stage of simmering to keep most of the heat down, oddly enough.  My beans are also 1/2 drained in the can to keep some starch in the chili, but not too much.
Finally, I serve jalapenos on the side for those that want it.

Wonderful! Only gets better with time, freezes well. I simmered it in the crockpot for about 6 hours after sauteeing the onion, garlic, and chilis. I also added some green pepper. To cut back on the fat, I added a can of fat-free cream of mushroom soup instead of the cheese. (I think this also cut some of the heat for the taste buds.) Also, I added a can of corn and subbed some black beans for one of the cans of white beans. Addictive!

This dish is great and not too difficult either.  I add more garlic, jalapeno, and onion and cook it slowly over medium-low heat for 1 1/2 to 2 hours with the lid off.  This reduces the chili down quite nicely, otherwise, you'll end up with a soup.  I've shared this recipe with several others and everyone has had great results.  Enjoy!

This was delicious. A wonderful soup for a cold winter night!! Here are the changes I made....2 cans white beans, 1 can black beans(for color and texture)3 cups chicken broth, 4 Tbsp water and 2 Tbsp corn starch to thicken it and 1/2 cup sour cream just before serving.  Top with more sour cream, cheese and chopped tomatoes. I also cut the jalapenos down to 1 Tbsp and cayenne to 1/4 tsp. but that is because I have 3 children under 3 years... I think I will increase it as they get older. :)

Wonderful soup! I cut the heat down by only using half a can of jalapenos and instead of a teaspoon of cayenne (ohmygosh!), just a few dashes. That left it with a nice spice, but the kids could enjoy it, too. I used mozzerella instead of jack, and added a good handful of chopped fresh cilanto in with the cheese. The first time I made it I'd been a little worried that it was too brothy, but that cheese at the end really does a lot to thicken it up and make it creamier.

text:
After having my sister-in-law's version of White Chicken Chili, I was interested in making it myself, so, of course, I came to Allrecipes.com!!  This recipe is SPECTACULAR!!!!  I didn't use canned broth though, only because I forgot it at the grocery.  I sauteed the onions, garlic, chilis and spices (added more of everything plus red pepper flakes, lemmon pepper, and garlic salt after reading another review) with 3 bouillion cubes and the chicken breast, then added water and the beans.  I also added some half and half to make it a bit creamier.  I didn't add the cheese to the soup.  I garnished with sour cream and shredded Jack cheese and a few drops of cayenne pepper sauce and between my husband, brother-in-law and myself, we finished off the whole batch in one night!!  My version may not be very healthy, but it sure was DELICIOUS!!!!!!

I made a half recipe, minus the cheese (didn’t have any) and it was delicious (I used one can chopped green chiles and one can  drained, rinsed  cannelloni beans and a container of 'no fat' 'no msg' chicken broth) and minced small half green bell pepper and half red bell pepper; made the chili colorful. Easy and quick, especially as I often have leftover cooked chicken breast meat (I used three small  baked chicken breasts, but would also use rotisserie chicken meat or leftover roast turkey)... A nice alternative to my regular chili. Yum.

text:
Super tasty! Our whole family had seconds. We took the other reviewers’ advice and didn’t add any jalapeños. My husband ended up adding Tabasco to spice his up. I had really wanted to make a slow cooker soup today so we doubled and added all the ingredients (except the cheese) into the slow cooker and cooked it on high for six hours. We used frozen chicken breasts and just cut them up near the end of the cooking time. We stirred the cheese in about five minutes before the end. We topped the soup with some broken tortilla chips. Magnificent!

text:
I subbed the jalopeno peppers with more green chili and for  my husband and I it was just the right amount of heat. The problem I have with the recipe is it came out way way way too watery. Really more of a soup instead of a chili. I personally love the flavor and and I don't think it is bland at all. It just tastes like beans and chicken with a subtle flavor which is great in my book. I do regret adding the cheese and it was against my better judgement to do so. The cheese just cools and sticks to things. I recommend adding it just when you serve it. I also recommend some fresh cilantro on top! YUM!! :)

text:
My family likes this when I temper the heat. I prefer it as written, with maybe a little more cumin and/or my own mix of Adobo seasoning. I have made this maybe 4 or 5 times and it's pretty fool proof.  The kids really like rotisserie chicken in it and in a slow cooker for a few hours on low.  Generally,  I've used pinto beans, but cannelloni beans are pretty tasty as well. As for the cheese, we are cheese folk, so anything goes for us.  For melting and blending, I've also tried conjita and Guerrero; I think mild cheeses or cheddar work better as an add-in and we top with the sharper varieties. Overall, great as written and very adaptable.

I had been saving the leftover bits from rotisserie chickens in the freezer for several months, and had just the right amount to make this recipe (it was actually closer to 4 cups so I added a little more chicken broth).  I'll be braver with the jalapenos next time.

text:
First time making this, and it turned out great!  I did not add the jalapeno peppers as I am not a fan of super spicy food.   I added a can of corn (drained) and used slightly less broth than the recipe calls for.  I added the cheese per serving instead of adding it directly to the entire pot of chili and added a bit of sour cream per serving as well.  Served this way, it was just spicy enough for me.  This makes a lot more than 4 servings in my opinion.

text:
We loved this recipe.  The only thing I changed was to use a 7 oz can of chopped green chilies and leave out the jalapenos, and reduce the cayenne pepper to 1/4 tsp.  I would have liked using the jalapenos but my husband prefers it milder.  I also used 3 cans of Campbells chicken broth (the 10.5 oz cans that you're supposed to add water to), but didn't add water.  And I did puree one can of the beans to thicken it up a bit.  Also sprinkled some cheese on top of the bowls instead of adding to chili.  We will definitely be enjoying this often!!

text:
I have made this many times and is a big hit for family gatherings. All ages and genders love it. great with sour cream and tortilla chips. can cut back on spice (cayenne and half the peppers) depending on crowd and set out hot sauce to taste for larger gatherings. We do not add the cheese, rather set it out for those who want to add it on top of their bowl as desired. If you use bone in chicken breast with ribs and boil, you get a good broth, if you have the time.

text:
I've been making this recipe for years, but with a few differences. I don't add the jalapeños, too hot, but I will add another can of green chilies making 2 cans total for the recipe. I also like my chili a little creamier so once the soup gets hot, instead of putting in the cheese, I add one cup of sour cream and 1/2 to 1 cup of whipping cream. It just makes the soup more on the creamier side which is how I like this recipe.

-1/2 tsp of cinnamon (it truly brings out the cumin)
-Paprika in addition to a dash of cayenne
-A can of diced tomatoes 
-I browned the chicken, onions, and garlic ahead of time with some flour to add more flavor
-1 tbsp (3 tsp) cumin instead of 2 tsp

I skipped:
-The chilis and jalapenos

text:
I Love this recipe.  I have modified it a bit to make it perfect for my family.  I use less of the jalapeño and reserve the rest for my husband as he likes more heat than I do.  I use my immersion blender to puree one can of white beans prior to adding it in,  this helps thicken it.  I add a can of corn as well.  I make extra because this is perfect for packing in lunches the next day! but be warned the original recipe is definitely spicy so if you are not a fan of a lot of heat, go easy on the cayenne and jalapeños.

text:
I had a small amount of leftover chicken that needed to be used, so I halved this recipe. To the onion, I also added a small amount of chopped bell pepper, and yellow and red pepper. I like spicy, but I always cut back on them because another person's idea of hot is probably different than mine. Too much can really wreck a dish, and you can always add more later if need be. I did add a bit of chile powder and some brown sugar. It seemed a little watery, but I'm thinking if you mash up some of the beans, it may add more thickness. Nice change from the standard beef chili. Thanks Cathy!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Hands down one of the best chili recipes ever!! Have made this for over ten years and altered to our tastes but it never fails to get rave reviews and requests. We use two cans of green chilies, 3 tbls of cumin and 1 each of chipotle and reg chili powder with a dash of cayenne. Two cans of white beans and one each of corn and rinsed black beans. We only individually sprinkle the cheese on top with dollops of sour cream but we love to eat this with rice (wild or white) while plating.  But we've also added rice to the simmering pot of chili for thickening as well as topped off the pot with milk to make it more mild for specific crowds. It's always better the next day and it is our annual after Thanksgiving meal to use up turkey!!

As many others said, it's WAY too hot if you follow the recipe (and I like spicy food).  So I typically use the 1 can of green chiles, just 1 spoonful of the jalapenos, and probably only 1/4 teaspoon cayenne.  I also don't stir in the cheese in order to keep it low fat.  I just put out shredded pepper jack or 2% cheddar to sprinkle on top if wanted.  We love this chili!

text:
Love the flavor, but like other reviewers I tweaked it.  I love hot, spicy food, but still cut the jalepenos to half a can, and increased the green chillis to 2 cans.  I only added 1/4 tsp of cayenne and it was still burn your lips hot!  I also tweaked the cooking directions as I was going to be out for a few hours and wanted flavors to blend well.  I sauteed chicken, onions and garlic together til chicken was cooked, then added chillis and also 3Tbs of flour as I wanted a bit thicker a chili.  I put this in a crock pot and stirred in the rest of the ingredients, except cheese (some of us added it later) and left it for a few hours...it was a hit with everyone!

FIVE stars as is for us hot food lovers!  If you have a more sensitive palate, make it milder with 2 cans mild green chiles and don't add the cayenne.  I like many others, dislike people who rate it based on their unique changes but I made it 99% true to the original except I didn't have cayenne but did have chipolte powder instead.  I served it with chopped cilantro, avocado, lime wedges, shredded cheese, tortilla chips and sour cream at a friends pot luck get together and allowed everyone to customize it to their preferences.  Everyone loved it on a cool Sept. evening.  Thanks so much for sharing.

I've made something close to this before. It's a recipe and I always play with them to get the taste I want. Very, very good. This recipe makes more of a hearty soup than a chili, I would say.  Didn't have green chiles, so I used a can of salsa verde, and only 2 cans of beans.  I think with the amount of broth, it could handle 3 cans but I made this in my crock pot and it was almost full to capacity.

userID:
2247871
Display Name:
Esther
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used the spices and proportions but made some modifications to accommodate my available ingredients. Instead of cooked chicken breast, I used 8 skinless, boneless chicken thighs, trimmed of fat and cut into 1" pieces. Because it was uncooked, I seasoned with salt and pepper and cooked in my Dutch oven in a Tbsp of vegetable oil prior to cooking the onions. When it was mostly cooked, I removed it and set it aside, then added another Tbsp of vegetable oil and the onions. I didn't have a can of green chilies, but I did have a poblano pepper, so I roasted it under the broiler, the removed the skin and chopped the pepper and added at the same step as listed. I also deglazed the pan with half the chicken broth, scraping up any flavorful browned bits from the bottom of the pan before adding the chicken and their juices, beans and the remainder of the chicken broth. At this step, I also added 1 14oz can of diced tomatoes, drained, and a small package of frozen corn. I brought it to a slight boil, then covered the pot, reduced heat and simmered about 15 minutes, until chicken was cooked through. Thighs are great because they remain so moist and juicy! This was a great recipe for using up miscellaneous fridge items (slow cooker white beans, diced jalapeños, poblano pepper)!

text:
The whole family loved this recipe.  I sauteed the garlic and onion first.  Then browned the chicken real well.  I then deglazed the pan with a splash of chicken broth and added 1 can of hot green chiles, 1 can cream of chicken soup and 2 cans white beans and 1 cup of chicken broth.  I then shredded the chicken and added that.  I let this simmer for about 3 hours on my stove and kept adding chicken broth to thin it out as it thickens as it simmers when cooking on stove top.  I garnished with a dollop of sour cream, shredded monterey jack cheese, diced tomatoes, chives and cilantro.  It was awesome!!!!

text:
I think this is one of the best chili recipes I have ever made.  I love spicy food and thought this was the perfect blend of spice, with one change.  I did not have any canned jalepenos on-hand so instead I used one fresh, seeded jalepeno and it was perfect.  For the beans I used 1 can garbonzo beans, 1 can cannellini beans and 1 can pinto beans.  Before adding the beans I put approx 1/3 of each can (unrinsed) into the blender, pureed and then added everything to the pot.  I also grilled my chicken which added a nice layer to the flavor.  This would be great to serve to a large group with a variety of toppings and add-ons (rice, crushed tortilla chips, avocado slices, pico de gallo, etc).

text:
It really is as good as they all say.  Like others, I changed it up a bit- sprayed my pot with Pam instead of using oil, used 2 cups chicken broth, pureed 1 can of white beans (which I drained before I realized the recipe calls for the whole can..... noxt time I will not drain), 1 can kidney and 1 can black beans both with juices, omitted the jalapenos and the cheese (calories) and cut cayenne in half (for the kids).  Kids even liked it!  Definitely  better when a little shredded cheese (fat free) and sour cream (fat free) were added but they are not necessary.

Based on the other reviews I made a few changes.  I only used 2 cans of beans since my family doesn't like beans, and I pureed one of the cans to thicken the broth. text:
VERY GOOD! Made it 4x's now. To save time, I put the chicken in a crockpot covered in chicken broth on low. Come home from work & shred the super tender chicken, then make the rest pretty much by the recipe. Only other thing I change is I blend a can or two of the beans instead of putting all 3 cans in whole. This helps make it thicker which we like. Note that the nutrition values are not accurate (more like deceiving). This makes about 4 quarts. The calories are based on 4 servings, but a quart is a big serving! I calculated that one CUP is approx. 230 calories...I have a big appetite & 1-2 cups of this is filling!

text:
I could see the original recipe being too "soup like" so I agree with other reviewers on a few modifications: 1) mash white beans to add thickness, 2) sub a can of cream of chicken soup instead of broth, 3) to make it really decadent, I mixed in half & half and sour cream along with the shredded cheese.  It was great... just adjust the peppers/cayenne for taste. I used shredded rotisserie chicken and served it over white rice. My dad added Cholula hot sauce to hi to kick it up a notch. Loved the leftovers!

text:
The only changes I made were I shredded the chicken instead of cubed and used about 3.5 cups of Chicken instead of 3. I also purred one can of the beans so the soup would be a little bit thicker. I also added in a half of a can of beer...Don't ask but it made it so much more flavorful and the beer cooks out. Once it was in my bowl I topped with a sprinkle of monterey jack cheese, a tbsp of sour cream and some pico de galo. Also can eat tortilla chips with it. I did cook it a little bit longer just so the beer would cook down and it would be back to the thickness I liked....Will definitely make this again...It was DELICIOUS!!! And no...it wasn't too spicy.

Although the amount of spices and jalapenos seemed daunting, the spiciness was “just right” after simmering. I wasn’t sure if the cans of beans were supposed to be drained or not, so I held onto the liquid at first. Then it was obvious that the chili needed more liquid, so in went the bean juice! I also added a can of Cream of Celery soup as suggested by other reviewers. Otherwise,  followed the recipe as shown. Served this to a group of skiers and they devoured it! No one complained that it was too hot.

text:
The first time I had this was at my Sister-in-laws home and it was great. Tasty and hearty. I am cooking it right now for my husband and it makes the house smell so so yummy. I used white cannelli beans, used a can of cream of chicken with herbs and 2.5 cups of chicken broth. The cream of chicken thickened up the soup so it isn't runny at all. The jalapenos I used have no heat so I added more cayenne pepper ( I love spicey food ). I didn't use oregano cos I don't have any...just used some dried italian herb seasoning. I also added about 1/2 cup of corn. I seasoned my chicken tenders with poultry seasoning and cooked it in the oven ( personal preference) so it's moist and flavorful. Going  to leave the cheese off to be added as desired during dinner paired with some garlic bread.

Rating:

helpfulCount:

userID:
1372476
Display Name:
Amy Wilson Walworth
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
28
favoritesCount:
356
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1453281.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm only giving 4 stars because I didn't follow the recipe exactly. I skipped the jalapenos and halved the cayenne, per others suggestions, because I knew it would be too spicy for my 2 little boys. I did puree one can of white beans to create a thicker consistency but it still came out more like a hearty soup rather than a chili. No worries -- still VERY tasty! I sauteed the onions and garlic in some olive oil and added to the chicken broth in my crock pot. Added the white bean puree, then blended in a bag of frozen corn and all my spices (garlic powder, onion powder, white pepper, cumin, cayenne, and about 3 T of dried cilantro)... I then sauteed my chicken in olive oil and a blended garlic herb spice, until it was just browned & added to the mix. Let that cook on high for about 2-1/2 hours in the crock pot and served with shredded col-jack cheese, sour cream, sliced jalapenos and chopped green onions. Also used the buttery cornbread recipe from this site. DEFINITELY going into the dinner rotation. Can't wait to make this again once it gets colder! Big hit with the family -- even my 2 yr old!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2011-08-12T10:18:16.887

text:
This is a pretty good basic recipe. My first time at making white chili. I sauteed a yellow onion, lots of garlic and a jalapeno pepper in some olive oil until soft. Then I added the shredded meat of two rotisserie chickens, four cans of white beans (I mashed the last can to a paste to make the chili thick), two packets of white chicken chili seasoning from McCormick, plus more cumin, pepper and enough chicken stock to give it the proper consistency. Very good with cornbread muffins.
