I thought this was delicious, easy and healthy! I left out both the jalapeños and the cayenne (because my kids won't eat spicy). That left it a little bland. I added 1/4 tsp salt and 1/8 tsp pepper and that wasn't quite enough; another dash of each in the bowl cured it and it was delicious. I used (very chicken looking) pork chops on accident and it still tasted great. To save effort I put the meat and the broth in the blender on low and it shredded the meat for me...very easy.

Awesome recipe!  I made this several times through Lent.  Everyone loves it.  I skillet-fry the onions and spices with veggie oil and then add the chicken broth.  I also add a good squirt or two of vinagre and a 1/4 cup of sugar.  In a slow-cooker, I put the beans and chicken and then pour the broth mixture over that.  I cook it on the low setting for 4-6 hours...DE-DILSH!  Everyone just adds their own cheese (and chopped green onions/cilantro) to individual bowls.

country:

text:
This is great. I have never made a white chcken chili, but love to eat them.  I didn't have everything on hand so this is what I did.  I had left over rotissiere chicken, I threw the carcass in a pot and put maybe 6 cups water in.  I let it stew while turning the chicken on occasion, maybe a total of an hour.  Removed the bird, pulled the meat off, returned the meat to the pot, liquid had reduced to about 4 cups.  I sauted onion, and a red pepper I had laying around, with the extra garlic.  Put it in the pot, dumped a can of corn with juice and 2 cans white beans, with juice in.  I didn't have jalapeno's or chiles (would have used a can of chile's if I had them).  Put in spices, reduced cayenne by just a little.  Wanted to thicken it up a bit, didn't have Monteray, so I put in a brick of cream cheese (next time I might only put in 6 ozs).  It is delicious!  Looking back, I thought the recipe called for corn so I threw it in.  It was a good addition.  But I had only done 2 cans of beans.

text:
As written four stars but this is very adaptable according to personal taste. It reminded me of traditional ham and beans with a mexican flair! Based on other reviews I pureed one can of white beans and eliminated a can of chicken broth. I used IQF chicken tenders and put them in the crock pot first and then added the remaining ingredients. I eliminated the cumin and peppers to tone it down. & added a can of diced tomatoes. Cooked on high for about five hours. Shredded the chicken and put it back in with about 3 Tbsp. of flour to thicken it up.  We love homemade soups and I'll be making this a lot. Thanks for sharing!

Great flavor!  Sauteed thigh & breast meat w/onion in olive oil to start; 7 oz green chiles, 1/2 can jalapenos; 1/2 tsp cayenne; 1-1/2 cans broth; added extra beans & hominy - all drained; + 1 can crm of chicken, undiluted, thickens it up. Needed salt, white pepper, coriander - But honestly - just fine as written, any other tweaks are just personal preference and it just makes sense to keep the heat down a bit and let people dr. up their own bowls if they want it hotter.  Cheese, sour cream, tortilla chips, avacado all on the side.  Yum!

This was SO good.  I used lentils, white kidney beans, and pinto beans.  I used two cans of chile's instead of the jalepenos and I used vegetable broth from concentrate. I didn't have some/all of the ingredients on hand and so I made a few alterations. First, I do not like beans so I left them all out. I love chicken chili with tomatoes so I added two cans of diced w/ green chiles  tomatoes with the juice. I only had one can of broth. I omitted the cayenne and cumin, but added a dash of paprika. Only diced about 6 slices of jalapenos and it was still spicy. We like it hot, so it worked but I probably wouldn't serve it this spicy to guests. Also, there was plenty of juice because of the tomatoes. Fabulous!! We usually use the packets at the store and this was much better.

None
text:
I love this recipe but a few modifications are a must. If you add more than a can of chopped tomatoes and chilies, you'll be breathing fire like a dragon. The one can was enough. I used the beans from the bag since I'm not a fan of the sodium that comes with the can. Once the beans we're ready, I simmered the broth, chicken, and other ingredients from the original recipe. I used thighs since they don't dry out. I definitely recommend adding some corn. It’s a nice touch. Added a can of cream of chicken to thicken it up (diluted with a 1/2-3/4 can of cream) 5 minutes before it was ready to serve. I forgot to add the cheese. It wasn’t missed.

text:
I just made this today and it was exactly what I was looking for.  I did make a couple of substitutions:  2 fresh jalapenos instead of canned, I roasted two poblano (mild) peppers and threw those in, and used a pre-made roasted chicken from the grocery store.  I did cut back on the cayenne pepper as well.  It is very tasty and can be customized for your likes/dislikes.  Will definitely make again!  The only reason I gave it 4 out of 5 stars is because it's more of a soup than a chili.  But by pureeing a bit of the beans or adding potato, it can be thickened to chili consistency.  Happy eating!

text:
Very good and full of flavor!  I read through a ton of the reviews and while I LOVE spicy food, I noticed many people saying it was way too spicy, so I used 2 cans diced chiles and 1/4t. cayenne and that was it for the spice.  And I actually went ahead and threw everything into the crock pot with two frozen chicken breasts and left it on high for about 1-2 hours and then on low for 4-5 hours.  SO easy.  All I had to do was take the chicken out before serving and shred it lightly...it just fell apart, it was so tender.  I also threw a cup or so of the mix (minus chicken) into the blender to thicken it up a bit which helped a lot.  Great recipe though.  Next time I may even add some corn!  Mmmmm.

This is a very nicely spiced chili. I used 3 large fresh Jalapeno's, I doubled the green chilies, and only 2 cans of white beans. To thicken, as I do even my Chili Verde, after all ingredients are sauteed, add 3 to 4 TBS oil to pan and 3 to 4 TBS flour, stir for about 30 seconds and add chicken broth. I used about a cup more chicken broth.

Display Name:
Meghan88
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/437405.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I absolutely loved this recipe! The first time I made it I followed the recipe almost exactly (modified for 8 servings). I did, however, substitute fresh diced jalapenos for the canned ones. The bright green of the fresh peppers really added a lot of crisp freshness to this chili. I like spicy things as do my friends, so we really enjoyed this. On my most recent venture with this recipe, I did make a few changes. The chili seemed really soupy the first time I made it, so in addition to the 6 cans of beans the recipe calls for (keeping in mind I make this for 8), I added 2 more cans of pureed white beans and one can of pureed black beans (this added wonderful color). This made the chili a lot thicker and much more "chili-like". I did find that I needed to add more cumin, cayenne, salt, and pepper since the beans did slightly dull the flavor. But after some spice tweaking, this made a WORLD of difference! Much, much heartier when you add the additional pureed beans. This is definitely going to become a staple in my winter recipe box!

Awesome way to use up leftover roasted chicken! My modifications: 5 cloves garlic; 1/2 fresh diced jalapeno instead of the can; 1/2 tsp cayenne; 2 cans of beans (plenty); added two fresh pablano peppers and a couple shakes of hot pepper flakes. I didn't measure the liquid, but I used water + 3 tsp of chicken bullion, and it was still too watery. Mine turned out mildly spicy, just about perfect, tho I think next time I'll use the whole jalepeno.

text:
Very good after reviewing some of the recommendations. From the original photo it looks way too thin so I also pureed one can of the white beans. I also added a tsp. of Chipolte Chili Seasoning. I used the 50% low sodium chicken broth too. Oh, the fiesta corn was awesome added to this! ;) 2 cans of broth is the perfect amount. I did not add the Jalapenos because I was afraid it would be a tad to spicy but I personally would love that. My kids thought it was too spicy but young kids can't usually tolerate heat but I thought it was mild. Next batch I will add the Jalapenos and add a full tsp. of Cayenne Pepper. I only used 1/2 tsp. for this one. It wasn't hot at all to me!    The texture is very good. Not too thin or too thick. Perfect...IF you follow some of the recommendations. The taste is very good and the spices are perfect.    A must try! Just add/subtract ingredients to your personal liking. ;)

UPDATE:

Using the Jalapenos makes this dish VERY hot. Most people will not be able to tolerate that so be selective here with your ingredients. I personally love to sweat eating soup. LOL! Very good!

Everyone who has tried this soup loves it. Make it without the Jalapenos if you plan to feed people you aren't familiar with. They may not like it that spicy.

text:
Fantastic recipe! I used 3 small fresh jalapeno peppers and roasted them, then took out all of the seeds. Did not use cayenne or green chiles to make up for that, but it was still EXTREMELY spicy. Luckily we love spicy, but next time we will probably only use 1 or 2 peppers to get more of the bean and chicken flavor. We also used dried beans (soaked overnight, then let the chili simmer for a little over an hour as opposed to 15 minutes), and used 2 cups homemade chicken stock and 2 cups of water. Also added a can of sweet corn and used cheese as garnish at the end. I used dried beans and fresh peppers to cut down on the sodium but then added my own salt near the end to bring out the flavors. Will definitely make again!

YUM- OF COURSE I CHANGED IT- I AM SURE THIS RECIPE AS IT READS IS VERY GOOD!! BUT TOO HOT FOR OUR TASTES- THINGS I CHANGED: 2 CANS GREEN CHILES- 1 CAN BROTH AND 1 CAN OF CREAM OF CHICKEN- 3 TEASPOONS OF CUMIN AND A SPRINKLE OF OREGANO (SOMETIMES IT IS TOO OVERPOWERING FOR ME) ONLY 2 CANS OF CANNELLINI BEANS- 2 LARGE BONELESS SKINLESS BREASTS THAT I SLICED VERY THIN AND COOKED WITH ONIONS- THIS IS ALL BASED ON THE SUGGESTIONS OF OTHERS- AND IT TURNED OUT DELICIOUS- I LIKE MY CHILI KINDA THICK- NOT LIKE SOUP AO THE CREAM OF CHICKEN HELPED AND I EVEN SPRINKLED IN A LITTLE FLOUR TO THICKEN FURTHER- FAVOR WAS GREAT--  MY HUSBAND, WHOSE PICKY AS HELL- SAID IT WAS AWESOME, HE WOULD GIVE IT 5 STARS AND WOULD EAT AGAIN- THATS LIKE AN OSCAR AWARD FOR HIM- THANKS FOR THE GREAT STARTER RECIPE!! IF YA LIKE IT HOT, I WOULD DEFINITELY TRY IT AS WRITTEN, IT IS JUST NOT OUR THING-

You go Cha Cha! I enjoyed this simple yet hearty white chili concoction. text:
Very good with the following substitutions: I used a 7oz can of chopped green chiles and omitted the jalapenos because i'm not really a fan.  I also cut the cayenne in half.  I love heat, but 1/2 teaspoon is perfect in my opinion.  I also used 4 cups of chicken stock instead of the 2 cans of broth, giving it a more pronounced chicken flavor.  To make the chili thicker, I mashed the beans up a little bit after adding them to the pot.  Absolute Mexican Cornbread is the perfect compliment to this chili.

text:
The best white chili recipe on this site!  I eliminated the oil & just used the juice from the can of chilies for moisture to sweat the onions.  I agree with other users about the heat, it's a bit much (and we love hot!).  So, I used 4oz. of diced jalapenos to 12oz. of green chiles, subbed 2t. chili powder for the cayenne.  I used 6 grilled chicken breast for the 6 cups (grilling added a nice flavor).  The beans I used were Mixed Beans (northern & pinto) & Canellini (white kidneys).  I also held the cheese out to use for garnish & a dollop of sour cream on top is always great!  My health nut daughter said "Wow, you could sell this stuff!"  Thanks so much for the post Cathy!!

I turned this into a crock pot recipe and it turned out great.  I added all the ingredients to the crock pot(minus the jalapenos and cayenne to keep the spice down). text:
We loved this. I made it in the crock pot by pouring all of the ingredients (except one can of the beans which I pureed as suggested by another member)over a frozen chicken breast and cooking it on low for about 5 hours. Then I removed it, shredded it and added it back to the chili. Next time I will only use one can of broth. I think cooking it in the crock pot rendered all the juices from the chicken and made it too thin. I also added a can of corn and 1/2 cup fat free half and half to it and served it with corn bread.

text:
Great base recipe. I actually changed a few things which makes this a great recipe to use to make something your family will love. Both my kids ate it up and hubby liked it too! I added three different white beans(what I had in pantry), a can of stewed tomatoes, can of corn, can of reduced fat cream of chicken soup and three cans of chicken stock. No peppers added and I did reduce the cayenne pepper. Hubby added own hot sauce. Served with tortillas and mexican cheese. Yummy!

text:
Excellent recipe with a few revisions: 1 tsp. of cayenne is way too much for our family (next time only 1/4 tsp.); added three (instead of two) cans of chicken broth; used 2 cans of green chile peppers (no diced jalapeno peppers); diced up chicken and cooked it along with the onion. Even though the cayenne pepper made this way too hot, we enjoyed it because I was able to dilute it down with the extra can of chicken broth. Thank you for sharing this with us.

This is delish!!  It is requested often at my house; even the picky ones gobble it up.  A few changes I make are I leave out the beans (not a bean eating family) and add two cans of corn.  Plus, right before serving I add one cup of sour cream.  This gives the soup a thicker consistency.  Served with homemade corn bread and salad rounds out the meal.

text:
This is a great recipe!  The first time I followed the directions exactly.  The next time, I tweaked it a bit.  I cut back the broth to one can and slow simmered the chicken in the broth along with the onion and garlic first, rather than cooking in oil.  Used more chicken.  When adding the beans, I included the juice from one or two cans, to make a desired consistency.  I used either green chilies or jalapeños, but not both ~ too spicy for most.  After the soup bowls were filled, cilantro was sprinkled on top along with slightly broken corn chips and a shredded Mexican three cheese mix.  Yum yum!!

text:
I get seriously impressed guests when I make this recipe!  My only changes are that I adjust the spices to my taste (fewer peppers, more other spices, and much less cheese to lighten it up a little), I shred a rotisserie chicken instead of cooking chicken separately, and I puree a can or two of beans to thicken the chili.  A squeeze of a lime wedge in the bowl before eating really brightens the flavor wonderfully.

text:
Great recipe but... after making it exactly as stated, I felt it needed a little more flavor (other than just the "hot").  Added 1 cup corn (for a little texture), a large can of diced tomatoes, 1/4 cup chopped cilantro, garlic powder, juice of a lime, fresh cracked pepper, and 1 tsp. chicken bouillion granules. (It wasn't just "white" chili anymore) but with just a few changes, for our tastes, we love this recipe. Thank you so much for this terrific recipe!

country:
None
text:
Very good recipe! I did as some of the other reviewers suggested. Cut all the hot from the recipe..no red pepper or jalapenos. I used 3 cans of green chile instead and a little more cumin. I also used 1 can of garbanzo beans instead of one of the white bean cans because that's what was in my pantry. I also added 1 can of cope's corn (dehydrated yellow corn in a can for those of you who are not familiar) It added an unexpected texture and a nice bit of sweet. I served the chili with jalapenos, sour cream, diced raw onion, and the cheese that was supposed to be in the chili on the side. For those of you who count point valus for food, if you omit the cheese in the recipe the point value is only 6 for a big bowl of this great chili. Definitely a keeper!

ekp333

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was AWEsome!  With the changes that I made this was just spicy enough and just hot enough.  I like spicy, but don't like food so hot that I can't taste it.  What I did was add the cumin by 1/2 t. until it was spicy enough and added the cayenne by 1/8 t. until it was hot enough.  This was perfect!
Here are the changes that I made:
did not use jalapeno peppers (yes, I was scared), used 2 cans diced green chiles, used 1 1/2 t. ground cumin, used 1/2 t. crushed oregano (uh..I ran out, would have used more if I had it), used 1/4 t. ground cayenne pepper, only used 2 cans beans (one butter, one pinto...closest I had to white beans and two cans was plenty), added 1/4 c. sour cream (I wanted it to be more opaque than it was).  Oh yeah, for the chicken, I cooked one large half of a boneless, skinless chicken breast right in the chili.  When it was cooked through (about 20 minutes), I removed it and shredded it and added it back into the pot.

I brought it to a chili cook-off and it got rave reviews.  Thanks, Cha Cha!

text:
This chili is AMAZING! This is one dish that my entire family asks for. The first time I made this it was way too hot for my children(they are 8 and 9). My husband and I LOVE spicy food and it was great. I played with the recipe and have made several amendments:
I use 6 cans of LUCKS  great northern beans...these are the thickest I have found and make it more of a chili
I do not use the jalapenos...I substitute a 4oz can of green chili peppers and serve jalapenos on the side
Cut down the cayenne to just a pinch
ADD 1/2 pint of heavy whipping cream...NO it is not healthy, but makes the chili DELICIOUS and controls some of the heat. I use 1 block of monterey jack  with peppers shreaded in to the chili and then add some to serve as a topping. IT IS AMAZING WE LOVE IT!

city:

country:

text:
I've been thinking about making this all week and finally found the time to do so. Since I haven't personally made home made chili like this accept from a box this recipe gets 4 stars. The 4 stars are based on the fact I don't have anything home-made to compare it to & the extra step I had to include. 1. Easy Ingredients to find in your local store. 2. Easy to follow directions for a newbie making White Chicken Chili. 3. Full of flavor, the cumin & cayenne are a perfect balance, I sauteed the peppers in with the onions after the onions began to become translucent as well as allowed the full 3 minutes for the spices to toast and really release their flavor. 4. A great meal for hubby and I since we both enjoy spicy meals.

Recommendations based on our experience with the recipe: Add this step to create a thicker & creamier chili base. Blend or process  about 2 1/2 cups of (mostly) beans & broth with what onions and peppers happened to fall in the ladle. Pulse a few times and return to the pot. Simmer on low until ready to serve.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
What a wonderful recipe!  On my first try, I didn't do so hot on following the cheesecake rules (don't overmix, waterbath, etc.) and had giant cracks criscrossing the cake, and the outsides were a bit too done.  My second attempt was fantastic - I used room temperature cream cheese (creams better with the sugar, no lumps - less mixing!), pierced the egg yolks before adding to the cake mixture to avoid over-mixing, and baked directly in a waterbath.  Just be sure to use 2-3 layers of foil around your springform pan to avoid cheesecake soup.  One more tip: add the vanilla with the last egg - I found that when added with the flour it sucked up the vanilla and made little brown lumps.  You'll get TONS of compliments!  I served with strawberry sauce (berries, sugar, bit of corn starch, then blended) and/or crushed Heath bar.  My mouth is watering just writing about it!

I'm sorry to say that I just don't care much for this recipe.  I made the chili (which is a soup, don't let the name fool you) according to directions, except for leaving out the jalapenos, since my kids won't eat anything that's hot.  There was just too much cumin -- and I love cumin!  I also found that even though I didn't use low sodium broth, this soup needed salt to make it palatable.  It didn't thicken at all, even though I mashed up one can of the beans and cooked it for almost thirty minutes.  I was disappointed and I won't be making this again -- maybe another of the chicken chili recipes on this site will be better.

text:
This was a hit at our Super Bowl party.  Very tasty and couldn't of been any simplier.  I did replace the jalapenos with extra can of green chili's.  I also cooked a whole chicken the day before and used white and dark meat.  For the white beans, we used Bush's Navy Beans.  I placed all ingredients in crock pot and slowed cooked for about 3 hours.  We added Colby Jack cheese when we served. Also, this recipes makes more that (4) servings as described.  But is great leftover too.  Everyone requested the recipe.  This will be prepared again & again at our house.  Thanks for the great recipe.

text:
Our all time fave chicken chili recipe! We LOVE spicy and this one clears the sinuses. If you want to less fat but a thicker texture, puree half the beans and leave out the cheese. You really don't miss it! This freezes really well. We generally saute uncooked chicken breast with the onion & spices when we back this. We serve it with cornbread. We always separate out part for our little girls before adding the jalapenos as they don't like spicy.

ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS!! Very different and original. We talked about how good it was non-stop. The only changes made were I used a crock pot. I like soups that simmer for a while for more infusion of flavors. I did sautee the onion first, but put small cut up pieces of raw chicken in the pot. I pre-cooked a heaping tablespoon of flour in broth to add- to thicken it-because it was a little too soupy for our tastes.  Following the other reviewers advice, I just used the green chili's and skipped the jalepeno's and it had the perfect amount of spice., and we do like spicey, Cooked on high 2 hours.

text:
I changed a few things. I only added about a Tbsp of the canned jalapenos, and instead of the chicken I bought a good-sized turkey breast, roasted it in the oven, and used the meat from that. (Do not over cook the turkey! Remember it will be cooked some more in the chili.) Also I just passed the grated cheese on the side. I also added some salt. With these changes, and served with warm flour tortillas, it's really great. My youngest had me make it for his 13th birthday party, and it was a big hit.

country:
None
text:
This turned out great! Good flavor. I made it a crockpot soup. Sautéed the onion and garlic first in oil on the stove for a few minutes. Then threw them on top of a large chicken breast (raw) and added remaining ingredients. Cooked for 6 hours on high. I left out the jalapeños and doubled the green chilies. And used 3 chicken bullion cubes with 4 cups water instead of chicken broth/stock. I think the cayenne is a key ingredient. Once completed i pulled the chicken breast apart with a fork to make it shredded in the soup.

userID:
5215895
Display Name:
HNY BNY
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
64
favoritesCount:
431
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4145275.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I somehow managed to buy regular chili beans (pinto) instead of white beans for this recipe. I decided to try it anyway. Still turned out wonderful. I adjusted the spices to my family’s liking and since I was being lazy, just threw the chicken breasts into my crockpot with all the other ingredients (except oil) and let it cook all day. When dinner time came round we shredded the chicken and put it back in the pot. The sauce was way too thin for us, so I took a cup (or more) of frozen diced okra and puréed it in my blender until no okra was seen. Tossed that back in the pot and we had a thicker (and healthier) chili. No one was the wiser and everyone loved it. I also just sprinkled the cheese on top, as not everyone in my family is a fan. I put the leftovers in to-go bowls for lunches and threw them in the freezer. Now I have yummy lunches in a snap.

country:
None
text:
I've prepared this recipe many times and absolutely love it. I love it for the great northern beans (not a bean fan-but these are the best  besides black). Also: it's easy, just a few ingredients, No Tomatoes! and it's very fulfilling and hearty tasting. I did change a number of the spices, I have a zero tolerance for Spanish hot. So I remove all Spanish spice and just add a half or whole 4oz can-depending on serving size-of green chilies. To me it's 'warm' but dull and non specific in it's hotness. I also reduce the chicken stock volume to half and I blend one can of beans of the total called for instead. Excellent recipe!! Love you for it, ChaCha!!

text:
Delicious!! I always cook the chicken while I cook the onion, and also add a bit more of the seasoning while the chicken is cooking,  I’ll use the same pot while doing this and also use about a cup of chicken broth while letting g the chicken cook.  Once that’s done I’ll pull the chicken and while it’s cooling to chop add the other ingredients into the pot.  I also use rotel instead of the separate jalepenos and green chili’s-it’s better suited to our toddler’s spice preference.  Top it of with cheese and sour cream if it’s your preference, and you have one yummy meal with some cornbread!

I’ve been making this recipe for a few years now and never tire of it!  I use 3 cans of green chiles and one can of diced jalapeños and cut the cayenne back to about 1/4 tsp. I use 3 cans of beans, one of them mashed up to thicken the chili. Rotisserie chicken works great for this too. Eliminate the cheese added in and instead serve on top with a dollop of sour cream and some scoop tortilla chips!

text:
I threw 3 frozen chicken breast in the crockpot just covered with chicken broth, for about 3 hours on high. Then drained that liquid. I shredded the chicken (super easy), added a half diced onion back and about a 1/2 carton of chicken broth back to crockpot, let that simmer for 1/2 hour, added cane of white beans, Italian seasoning, salt, pepper, 2 cloves minced garlic and let it simmer another 1/2 hour. My fam ate it up. We added sliced avocados, sour cream and my kids scarfed it down with tortilla chips. YUM. Thanks for the recipe

text:
I thought this was absolutely fantastic.

I like a watery chili, but my wife prefers thicker chilis, this will come out watery as is.

Others have suggested pureeing a can of beans to add in to thicken it, and my wife suggests flour. Your choice.

I prefer to go full board with the jalapenos, if it's too spicy I suggest a dollop of sour cream, or load up on cheese.

All in all, very delicious.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4095255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a tremendous recipe. It has become a staple in my house. however... I have to cut the cayenne pepper, chili's,  and jalapenos in half. I love the flavor of cumin so I don't cut that more than 1/2 teaspoon. The thing is, I grew up on spicy foods. I LOVE spicy foods. But if I made this without cutting the peppers, I wouldn't be able to eat it. It has serious heat. by cutting the peppers in half, it is at the highest heat level that I can tolerate. My reason for saying this is, if you are someone ago doesn't like really spicy foods, you need to cut the peppers by at least half. But I definitely wouldn't omit either the chili's or the jalapenos. you need both for the flavor. omitting one would alter the flavor.
Review:
Rating:
5

Display Name:
Angelagrace503

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious, I read others reviews and did a couple alterations to fit my tastes. I don't like things too spicy and I like soups on the chunkier and creamier side so here's the changes I made. I didn't add any jalapeños and used 2 x 4oz cans of mild green chiles. I smashed one of the cans of white beans to give a creamier texture and also added a can of strained navy beans for extra chunkiness. I added More cheese than it called for (added to taste) and served with a dollop of sour cream and more cheese sprinkled on top. To save on time I got a store bought pre cooked rotisserie chicken and used all the meat I could get off of that (ended up being about 4 cups of cooked shredded chicken). It still turned out a tad spicy so I might use a little less cayenne next time. We loved it immediately and it was even better the following day.

text:
I've been making this for years and have never met anyone who did not love it.  I take it to potlucks, make for parties or just for my own picky eaters and it's always a hit. I generally make it just as written but it's easy to tweak.  I don't like cheese so have never added it.  when I share the recipe I let people know there is no cheese and how much they should add, but most people feel it's great as is and never end up adding the cheese.    Based on who I'm feeding I add/subtract the amount of chili peppers/jalapenos, spices.  I usually just smash up one can of the beans to help thicken the chili since I don't use cheese. Great recipe that has been shared many times!

userID:
9212711
Display Name:
alicebelle
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:
0

0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this dish for a couple of years now. It is one of our favorite soups, and my family prefers it to tomato based tortilla soup.   I like it because it is easy, quick and delicious!  

Often, I use 2 cans of northern white beans and 1 can of three bean blend (black, kidney and pinto).  I always leave out the jalepeños and cayenne, as my family doesn't dig that sort of thing.  I serve options like  cheese, tortilla strips, avocado, sour cream.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-06-11T00:59:33.01
helpfulCount:

text:
This was delicious! I made it for little bitty ones, my mother and grandpa who can't handle spicy, and my father and I, who both love spicy. I omitted the jalapeños and just did 8 oz of green chiles, and cut the cayenne in half to be safe. It wasn't spicy at all, but full of flavor still. My picky 3 year old sister said it was "awesomeness." And us spicy-lovers were still satisfied without the heat. We ate it with tortilla chips, it was a good combo.

country:
None
text:
We like spicy chili so the spices here were great for us but may be too hot for some. Second the amount of liquid that the recipe calls for is fairly high. I cut the liquid in half and then even use a quick slurry to thicken it up a bit while it simmered.

Another step I took was I did this in a fairly big pot so I cooked the chicken in the pot first removed it, then did the onions in the chicken fat and a bit of broth. Then added the rest of the ingredients as noted. Turned out great! AS usual a recipe is just a guideline for anyone. Make it your own.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG, this recipe. So simple, but grand. Really, incredible. I made a few changes because I prefer my chili to be thick. If you do as well, follow these tips. 

Puree one can of the beans. 
Simmer for longer to burn off extra water and mend flavors (or make your chicken broth 'denser') 
Add a can of cream of chicken (if you like it creamy) 

The other things I changed... 
One fresh jalapeño instead of canned
Reduction in cayenne 
Chicken heavily seasoned with cumin, salt, pepper and garlic while cooking

This recipe is amazing and a staple in our household now. Seems like it can easily be thrown into the crock pot as well which is such a plus.
Review:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one of the easiest recipes to make because you can substitute fast solutions when necessary.  Fresh chicken, slightly frozen cuts the easiest and when thrown in towards the end of cooking will make the chicken nice and tender, but if you're in a hurry, you can get away with using canned chicken, juice and all.  The canned juice actually adds a bit of flavor and as long as you use a quality canned chicken it still tastes great.  I also added about 1/2 c. of sour cream near the end to add a creamy flavor and texture and I garnish this with Cilantro.  Another great add is dill.  Dill is great with this dish as well.

text:
This was very easy to make but I didn't have all the ingrediants...I substituted 3 cans hominy for the beans...2 large cans chicken for the raw chicken...3 TB chopped garlic in oil for the garlic cloves...1 (7 oz can) chopped green chiles and 2 cups Colby-Jack instead of Monterey Jack.  I, also, topped each bowl with a large dollup of sour cream.  Everyone loved it!  I usually put both hominy and white beans in my white chili because it seems more hearty to me that way but this is real good, too.

Display Name:
Virginia Wichman

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7281893.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The flavor is absolutely outstanding!  And that is without the cheese yet.  So I did make it a tad different....I started with frozen boneless, skinless chicken breasts (3) and cooked them in the chicken broth.  Then I took the meat out, shredded it and set it aside while I strained the broth...it had a lot of chicken gunk in it :(  While the meat was cooking, I chopped the onion and garlic and measured the seasonings.  Sauteed the onions, garlic and seasonings according to directions then added about 1/2 of a fresh jalapeno (diced) with the seeds removed and a small pack of Hatch, New Mexico green chiles that I had in my freezer (grilled with skins removed before freezing)...probably 3 times what the recipe called for.  Added the strained chicken broth and simmered it for about an hour before I added two cans of S & W chili seasoned white beans with liquid (didn't have 3) The aroma is amazing and the flavor is unbelievably good!  Can't wait to try it with the Monterey Jack cheese.

text:
So delicious! Thanks to the previous reviewers, I toned down the spiciness and seeded the jalapeños before chopping and adding to the chili. I used two drained cans of Great Northern beans, and added about 12 oz of leftover homemade pureed white bean soup to the mix. I used about 2 cups of chicken stock made from pouching two large skinless boneless chicken breasts and added a tsp of "Better Than Bouillon." The chicken was shredded and I put everything into a slow cooker on low for a few hours.  Thanks for an awesome chili!

This was very good! I have a young son who doesn't like a lot of spice the rest of us REALLY enjoy spicy, but for the sake of our youngest I opted to omit the Jalapenos and use a second can of green chilies as suggested. I  only used 1/4 tsp cayenne. I used a cooked Costco chicken ( measure out 3 cups of meat) and froze the rest for future use. Used the carcass to make my own broth, Only used 14.5 oz of the broth and pureed one can of beans. I added the cheese to the bowls as I served them.  Everyone LOVED it. Served with sweet corn bread cake. This is a keeper! Thanks Cathy!

text:
I mostly followed this recipe.  I read the reviews  and left out the jalapenos and reduced the amount of cayenne.  I found that this left the chili not spicy enough.  Next time, I will keep the cayenne at the normal amount.  I found that 2lbs of chicken was sufficient to feed 4 people with left overs.  I did add a can of cream of chicken soup and still used 2 cups of chicken broth.  I did not need to puree some of the beans.  The chili was thick enough and not soupy at all...I found the amount of cumin, oregano, and garlic to be great.  It was easy to make and not time consuming at all.  I cooked this in a cast iron pot for a camping meal.

I've made this recipe several times now. Like others have mentioned, I eliminated the jalapeño and substituted 1 can of mild green chilies in. userID:
14417899
Display Name:
Care Lykins Burpee
isPro:

4

11

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1527550.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We love this as a basic recipe, but I do make a number of changes, as it is far too spicy as written. I TRIPLE the recipe, so all of my suggestions are based on that quantity. Instead of 3 cans each of the peppers, I use 2 cans of the jalapeño peppers and 3 of the diced green chilis. Instead of 6 tsp. of cumin, I put in 4 slightly rounded. Instead of 3 tsp. of cayenne pepper, I put in 1 heaping. I make the chicken really easy by using a large (50 oz.) can of diced chicken. Made as written, the recipe is more of a soup; since we like our chili thicker, I only use 1 large cardboard container (32 oz.) and 2 cans (14.5 oz.) of chicken broth. Using these quantities, we get a chili that is just the right heat and fits in my large crock pot perfectly (I throw everything in at lunchtime and put it on high for a few hours, then down to low when we leave for after school activities. It also works to put in on low for the whole day.).
Review:

This was excellent chili. I made some revisions due to necessity and desire. Added only one can of green chilis. With that and the cayenne pepper was plenty spicy for us. The cheese I had on hand was a Mexican blend, which worked out perfectly. Ok, everything's not white for sure, but it's sure good.

What an easy recipe that tastes awesome! I go light on the spices as a personal preference and used black beans since that was what I had, and added a little Salsa (Verde or Traditional) for a little zing.  It is so easy to through together.

userID:
17015854
Display Name:
Richard Homier
isPro:
False

0

0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2963913.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this a few times and like most reviews I think it is hot so I now use the mild chilis, cut the jalapeños required in half and use a pinch of cayenne and if I think it needs more towards the end I add another pinch stir and let it simmer in for a couple minutes and taste again, I'll do this until it's got the desired bite.  The cumin I think is the spice that gives the chili it's unique flavor so I usually  add whats in the recipe.  I'll also substitute 1 can of rinsed black beans for a can of the white beans just to give it some color and then add a small can (or a few large spoons) of drained corn.  I've found what works best for the chicken is I'll buy a cooked rotisserie chicken and use both the dark and white meat, it's moist, tender, flavorful and really easy.  Adding the cheese at the end is what thickens it up and it helps a little in cooling the spice down a little.  Take some sour cream and thin it out just a little with milk and drizzle over the top.  Best Chicken Chili you'll probably ever have !!

text:
This was delicious, but I did have to tweet it a little. After reading other reviews, I only used one can of chicken broth and added one can of cream of chicken. This made the sauce nice and creamy. I also put in 1/2 the jalapeño and 1/2 cayenne. I didn't have green chillies on hand so I just omitted them. I also added one can of black beans and one can of corn. It gave the dish some color and added flavor. I also didn't have any Monterey Jack cheese, so I just used cheddar .  I served it with brown rice. The amount of spices I put in was just right. The heat wasn't overbearing but gave the dish a nice spicey zing.  My family loved it!

As with most recipes we tailor for our families, it always takes a great base recipe to begin with. This is delicious the way it is, but when you have a family of 6 to please....I always have to double the recipe (or we'd run out mid-meal because of our two teenage boys) omit the jalapenos, double the green chiles,  double the chicken, use taco seasoning instead of cumin/oregano/cayenne mix, and use a potato masher at the end to thicken it up. Yummy!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Note: I've read some add everything into the pot and then begin cooking. I do make some soups this way, but this particular soup is amazing if you take the time to saute the onions, garlic and jalapeno before adding the stock. If you make it this way add some flour just before adding the stock and it makes a lovely thick soup. On with my review: I made this lovely recipe and it's spot on. After making it as it is listed I decided to up the ante a bit (not because it needed it, but because I had some items I needed to do something with. I had some lacinato kale that needed harvesting a bit so I added a good hand (bunch) chopped finely. I added some of my fresh herbs; rosemary, oregano and parsley. I also added a few small bay leaves to my chicken breast and stock along with some black peppercorns. I had half a smoked turkey sausage left from a gumbo I made over the weekend so tossed that in as well (I would have normally added pimenton for the smokey flavor.) I like making a BIG soup kettle of soup so I can freeze some for those work lunches and weeknights I don't feel like cooking so added a large and small potato to thicken up the big pot of stock.  I love this versatile recipe! Thank you for sharing.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe as instructed, except I used 1/4 tsp of cayenne instead of 1 tsp. At the grocery store you will likely have the choice of mild or hot green chiles in a can. I chose mild.  I like the flavor and spice of jalapenos, so I kept them in. The flavors were hot, but pleasantly so. Definitely not unbearable. It had a good kick.  Of course this is all to each person's taste--what is mild for one person is too hot for another. If you are concerned about the heat level, use mild green chiles  and play with the amount of cayenne. You can also buy "tamed" jalapenos in a can, if you want the flavor but not the heat. FYI--this chili is actually more green than white, if that matters to you.

This a keeper! It is spicy but that's the way we like it. Too many "chicken" or white chili's are bland...but not this one. Also served w/a dap of sour cream which helped to cut the heat. This will be my go to recipe if I want to serve a white chili variation.

I used a pound of ground chicken and only chopped it up a little bit, not crumbly not  too chunky then set it aside in a bowl.
I only had a red onion and used fresh garlic. Jalapeños fresh too, 1 large, diced no seeds.
I used 2 cans of cannelli beans and 1 of garbanzo beans, 1 can corn, all mostly drained but not rinsed. 1 can of chopped green chiles. I used a heaping teaspoon of oregano and used the cumin and red pepper and chicken broth  as directed. I used half cup Colby jack and half cup pepper jack cheese.
Best recipe ever. Got rid of the others!!! Tyty :)
Suzanne.     Ann Arbor,  MI

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Based on other reviews I was a bit wary of making this too spicy for my daughter, so I skipped the jalapenos and used two 4 oz cans of chopped chilis instead. I also used some chili powder, and the spiciness was just right- enough for the adults, not too much for the kid. I used one can of chicken broth, two 19 oz cans of white beans, plus added a can of corn. Also, 5 (!!) cloves of garlic, which was (thankfully) fine. It was a little watery so I added about 1/2 cup of shredded mozzarella 15 mins before serving, it thickened up nicely.

From another recipe I made some avocado/sour cream topping (1 avocado, 1/3 cup sour cream, 2 teaspoons lemon juice, dash of salt), it was perfect on top of the chili.

Great recipe, will definitely make again - thanks!

city:

country:
None
text:
I have to preface, that I DID make slight changes, because I prepared this in a crock-pot.  I hate it when reviews are changed, but this was just too good not to review.  I made pretty much exactly as is, except I had the chicken already cooked and shredded, I used fresh jalapeno from garden, and I only used half of cayenne pepper.  I placed all items in crock pot for the entire day.  I did not add the cheese, as the recipe called for, but I wanted a thicker chili, so about an hour before serving, I made a mixture (from an old chicken stew recipe I have) to thicken - mix 1/4 milk and three tablespoons of flour - blend well and add 3 tablespoons of sour cream.  Add to crock pot and cook on high until ready to serve.  This was delicious and I will be making again - thanks for the recipe!!

Great and healthy, hearty meal.

This is definitely a keeper for my family!

text:
This recipe is HOT!!! I used the jalapenos only, thinking the chili's and cayenne would be too much.  We like our food spicy, but I had to use potatoes to draw some of the spiciness out. Outside of the heat, the chili is on the bland side.  We had rice on the side or chili over rice, and cornbread. Sour cream also helped cool down the peppers.  Be very aware of the spice.  Maybe use the green chili or cayenne and add jalapeno if necessary.  I wont be making this again.

text:
Per other reviews: Cut back on peppers and cayenne pepper as it is very spicy as is.  Put everything into a crock pot (including the uncooked chicken) and let it all cook together. #2. I puree the white beans before putting them into the mix. This makes it much thicker and chili-like. #3. Once the chicken is cooked I shred as opposed to chopping it. I also don't use that much chicken broth - maybe a cup or a cup and a half.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really good. I gave the four stars because I omitted the cayenne, jalapeno and chile peppers. I added cinnamon and chili powder instead. I used a can of cannelloni beans and a can of chili beans. I took some chicken thighs and simmered them for an hour. Shredded them, put them aside. I browned some sausage, drained it and used a tablespoon or so of the grease to saute the onions, garlic and green bell pepper with the seasonings. I dumped the mixture of chicken, sausage, veggies and beans into a big pot with a can of cream of chicken soup mixed in. I used the reserved chicken broth and eyeballed it, adding a small amount here and there; enough so that I was happy with the consistency. A thick, delicious meal served over rice.

text:
This is delicious.  Although, as many others have mentioned, VERY spicy.  I cut back a little on the spicy stuff and it's still a little too spicy for me.  I chopped up 4 small jalapenos in place of the can of jalapenos, and I cut back a little on the cayenne.  I think next time I might leave the cayenne out entirely or maybe use just a sprinkle.  I think the jalapenos OR the cayenne would be good, but not both!  However, other than that I am very happy!  I served it over fritos, because that's how I first had white chili and it is soooo good that way!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Very good recipe. I always read both positive and negative reviews before making a new recipe. I see that there are people who say they found this "bland" and then I see people who find this "too spicy". The way you clean your jalapeños would make the difference. The more seeds you remove and discard, the milder the flavor. I really liked the flavor of this soup and will make it again. My only confusion was that the recipe said 3 cups of chicken and 3 cans of white beans yielded FOUR servings. I used 1can of white beans and 1 1/4# of ground chicken. I added a can of retried beans to make a thicker soup.

text:
We loved it. I got the mild nacho style jalapenos and mashed 1 can of the beans and added some frozen corn, after reading the reviews. I didn't change the other ingredients except that I used about 4 oz. of cream cheese stirred in at the end since it was the only cheese I had at the time.  Hubby brought home some cheddar later and we used it on top.  Due to picky kids who don't like onions, I sauteed the onions then used my immersion blender on them with some of the broth and they never knew they were in there. I use this trick a lot, and sometimes I add the garlic to the onion mix to blend because my husband doesn't like garlic or onions.  What they don't know won't hurt them I guess!

text:
I loved the recipe but made some modifications based on a coworker making it first. It was a little on the liquidy side and really spicy even with slightly reducing the amount of cayenne. But when I made it I reduced the cayenne in half and then I only put half of the jalepenos in. I don't eat onions so I left that out. Instead of cubing the chicken I boiled it (no oil necessary) and then shredded it and it thickened it up better. In one ob of my bowls I also added cooked brown rice which was really good too and I served it with a side of french bread. You could do one more can of beans if you don't want to add rice or you could substitue the beans for rice or noodles to make a soup. It was tasty. Still on the spicy side but when I added the rice it did help. Going to make it again this weekend.

text:
EXCELLENT!  But this is more of a soup than chili!  Prepared exactly as stated, but used fresh jalapenos-fresh is best!  I like a thicker "soup", so before adding chicken, I used an immersion blender in the pot, pureed one can of beans, and then added the 2 additional cans "as is".  
This IS a spicy "soup", so if you can't take the heat, reduce cayenne pepper by 1/2.  
Thanks for sharing your wonderful recipe!

text:
Served at a family New Years Day gathering as an alternative to traditional red chili.  Everyone who tried it raved about it.  Doubled the recipe with these modifications:  used 1 can of jalapeno and 2 cans of green chilis (heat was just right) and 4 cans of white beans vs. 6.  Pureed one of the 4 cans of beans to thicken up the consistency.  Finally, we added some cilantro. Other than that, every other ingredient was doubled.  Prepared the day before in the crockpot and let cook for 5 hours, then reheated on the day of the party. Served with shredded cheese, sour cream, chopped scallions and cilantro.

text:
This recipe is wonderful!  I can't tolerate too much heat, so to tone it down I only use 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper and a fresh diced jalapeño with seeds and ribs removed.  The first time I made it it was incredibly hot, but I successfully turned down the heat with HONEY, yes that's right, honey-it doesn't affect the flavor at all.  A tbsp of honey cuts the heat in half and it was super delicious, though still a little hot.  I also boil my chicken (I used 2 fresh chicken quarters with skin on) to make my own stock-with a little salt.  Then just remove the skin and shred it by hand after its done!  Delish!

I woke up this morning with plans to make white chicken chili.  After looking at the reviews, I decided on this one.... and I'm glad I did.  It turned out so good, I had a bowl for breakfast.  I made it close to the recipe, but used only 2oz jalapenos, and elimated the garlic.  I love garlic, but no one loves me when I eat it!!  I pureed the jalapenos with the green chilis and pureed one can of the beans.  I used 2 cans of navy beans and one great northern.  I didn't add any cheese and it is delicious, and healthier.  Maybe the next time I make it I will rinse the beans to lessen the sodium.  It's excellent as is, but I don't need the salt.  Going for a 2nd bowl.... and it's not even 9am!

text:
I made this today for a football party. I doubled the recipe (for a large crowd). I did make a few changes: I used 2 rotisserie chickens. I used the skin and bones from the chicken to make my own broth.  Added bay leaf, celery and onion to the broth and brought to a boil.  When I thought it was ready, I set it aside until i was ready for it.  I pureed 2 cans of great white northern beans with a whole jalapeno, seeds and all.  I then strained the broth and mixed it in my slow cooker with the bean puree, added the chicken, 3 cans white kidney beans (drained), and the onion garlic and spice mixture.  The color is beautiful and smells incredible!  And, if I must say so myself, it tastes pretty good!!!

Great recipe! I took the advice of others here and there. I used three different white beans and a can of corn - I drained every can. I subbed one can of broth for a cream of chicken soup. I skipped the cayenne and used that amount of chili powder instead, which I think helped cut down on the spiciness that a lot of people complained of. Lastly, I mixed in a cup of sour cream when I put in the cheese. Then I topped with extra sour cream and cheddar. It was phenomenal!!

None
text:
Made my own chicken broth using two large bone-in chicken breasts, whole carrot, whole onion, 3 celery stalks, a handfull of fresh parsley, salt, pepper, and enough water to cover.  Simmered on stove top for 1 to 1.5 hours. Strained liquid, reserving enough broth for the chili.  Chopped chicken and reserved for recipe.  Omitted canned jalapenos, but sauteed a whole fresh jalapeno, seeded, with the garlic and onions.  Finished the soup as directed, using half the amount of red pepper. Served with chopped cilantro, scallions, and Mexican sour cream sides.  Also served the cheese on the side...didn't stir it in.  Delish!

text:
Really good!  I used chicken leg quarters, which I cooked in the slow cooker with about 1/2 cup of water.  Then used the juice in the slow cooker as my chicken broth.  I also used extra green chilis instead of jalepenos because I was making this for my whole family, includng children.  All of us, even the kids, ages 2, 5 & 7, ate this & liked it.  I also cut back on the spices, using less cumin & cayenne.  We added the cheese to our individual bowls, along with sour cream & crushed tortilla chips.

Just made this again for the second time. It was just two of us, so I scaled it back. I will definitely make this again..it is SO good!

text:
This is a really good recipe....after I tweaked it. The recipe as is, is rip your lips off SPICY! Not for the weak or the faint of heart. I can usually withstand some pretty spicy food, this will rub your taste buds raw.  I cut the cayenne back to 1/2 a tsp, and only used about 1-2 tsp. of the canned chopped jalapenos. Even with the cut backs, it still has a pretty solid kick. The chicken I used was left over from a rotisserie chicken from the previous night, a great way to use up left overs. Also added about 1/4 half n half for extra creaminess.

country:
None
text:
One of the best chili's I've ever had (sorry mom). Using the chicken broth instead of tomato sauce gave it a much lighter consistency. With all the spices and peppers added made the end results very spicy, just the way I enjoy it. Warning: If you're not one for the really spicy foods, I would recommend cutting back on some of the Jalapeños and spices. Another tip would be just before adding the cheese at the end use a hand mixer to chop up some of the chicken and really mix those ingredients together. and like any stew or chili it only gets better the longer you let it sit. So don't worry about rushing it.

text:
UPDATE: MADE THIS AGAIN TODAY, BUT THIS TIME I PUREED AN ENTIRE CAN OF BEANS TO GIVE THIS A CHILI-LIKE CONSISTENCY (AS IS, THIS IS QUITE SOUPY). I ALSO ADDED JALAPENOS AND THE FULL AMOUNT OF CAYENNE CALLED FOR (SPOT ON!) AND COOLED MY CHILI A BIT BEFORE ADDING THE CHEESE (PERFECT!). Meh. This was just "OK." My fiance is out of town on business, so I decided to invite my folks over for dinner (and sneak in a house project for my dad to help me with lol!). Dierdre Dee's white chili I recipe is my stand-by, but I have always wanted to give Cha Cha's recipe a try to see if it's any better than hers. I must say, I am going to remain loyal to Dierdre. While I enjoyed this, I didn't as much as  Diedre's (sorry!). To be fair, I must admit I changed things up a bit. I did not use jalapenos (I used all green chiles) and decreased the cayenne to 1/2 t (to accommodate my mom's sensitive palate). I also added a 15.5 oz. can of white (shoepeg) corn simply because I wanted to use it up. My only regret was adding the cheese to my chili. Not only did my cheese NOT melt, it stuck to the bottom of my Dutch oven (and was a PAIN to clean!!!). I would have much rather reserved the cheese as garnish. Served bowlfuls garnished with crushed tortilla chips, green onion and sour cream. Bluegirl's golden sweet cornbread (another favorite of mine!), a tossed salad with avocado ranch salad dressing (Randesgirl) and caramel apple enchiladas (ReDonna) completed our meal. Thanks for sharing, Cathy! :-)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
SOOOOOO yummy!  I did make a few changes to suit our tastes and healthy eating endeavor.  I used boneless, skinless chicken breasts and seasoned them with Mrs. Dash Southwest Chipotle seasoning prior to cooking in a nonstick skillet with no oil.  I also browned a pound of ground white turkey and seasoned that with the southwest chipotle seasoning.  The combination of chicken and turkey was delicious, and healthy.  I also only used 2 cans of cannelini beans as other reviewers suggested, and instead of green chiles I used a can of regular Rotel.  I also added a can of stewed tomatoes, a cup of corn, and chopped cilantro.  Finally, I omitted the cheese and put 1 Tbsp on each bowl for garnish instead.  This way, each 1 cup serving was only 138 calories with 2 grams of fat!!  My husband and I love spicy food and this was perfect for us, even with the additional Southwest Chipotle seasoning I used on the meat.  I suggest other people try using regular Rotel instead of green chiles, it'll help tone down spice while adding some flavor.  I can't wait to eat the leftovers!

Yummm!  Great flavor and spice!  I followed the recipe the first time i made it, but made a few changes my second go around.  As suggested by a previous reviewer I added a can of corn and added a 1/2 can of cream corn to add thickness.  I also put one can of white beans in the blender with the liquid to made it creamier without having to add cream.  I chose not to add oregano and used coriander instead of cummin and added a tsp of pepper.  I also added 1/4 cup fresh cilantro and garnished the chili with Monterey jack cheese and sliced avacado. text:
GREAT recipe!  I added a couple more cans of beans, yet pureed them so that it would thicken the sauce.  I also added a can of corn, and used a jalapeno and a 7 ounce can of chili's.  Spicy-ness is good with this amount of peppers.  Also, substituted the chicken broth for the water that I boiled the chicken in while cooking (probably about 32 ounces of water).  A little extra salt made this substitution a less-expensive recipe and tasty as well!  All-in-all a VERY good recipe without any modifications!    Oh, I left out the cheese and opted to allow it for use at the table if needed.  Also, sour cream is a great garnish in the bowl.  Wonderful.

This recipe is okay, but i felt like it needed some extra zing.  I don't like hot food so i omitted the jalapeno completely.  I cut the amount of oregano and cumin in half (i felt it was overpowering).  I only added about 1/4 tsp cayenne.  I added 1/2 T of chili powder. I would reccomend serving with a T of sour cream on top and with corn chips.  These changes made it closer to a 5 star.

This has good flavor, but it's HOT as-is.  I would give it 5 stars, but the first batch we ended up throwing out because we couldn't eat it.  The 2nd batch we omitted the jalapenos and added corn starch to thicken it up and it was MUCH better.  We also only added 2 cans of beans instead of 3 and added more chicken, as my husband likes his a little more "meaty".  Overall, great recipe with modifications.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2010-02-05T13:23:57.81
helpfulCount:

text:
This soup was really spicy, but was super tasty. I made the following alterations after reading others reviews and after tasting it during the cooking process:  - I only used 3/4 can of peppers - I added in 1 can of white corn - I added in 1 can of diced tomatoes to add some more vegetables and color - I added in a little more chicken broth than called for, as it was very spicy - I blended up half the beans with an immersion blender - I topped off the chili in my bowl with cheese and some Greek Yogurt.

text:
This was great!  I added a few things to suit my parents' tastes since I was cooking it for them. I added a can of corn and a can of rotelle tomatoes, and left out the jalepenos and green chiles. I used 1/8 tsp of cayenne. Taking out some of the spice but using the mild rotelle tomatoes made the perfect amount of spice for my mom who doesn't mind spicy, as long as it's not too spicy. I also used 1 can of broth and 2 cans of cream of chicken, because i liked the texture better that way. Instead of putting the cheese in the pot, I put a bowl of a Mexican mix of shredded cheese on the table. very yummy!

text:
Based on other reviews I was prepared to alter the recipes as follows: cut out jalapeno peppers, double the green chile peppers, substitute 1 can of chicken broth with cream of chicken soup, and use 4 cans of beans w/ one can mashed. However, as I was making the chili I was worried about it becoming too soupy. I drained the cans of beans before adding them. After I added two cans, I thought it look like enough beans so that is all I used. I have five young children so I cut the cayenne pepper by 1/2.  The thickness came out perfect...not too soupy, and it wasn't too spicy either. Will definately make again. Thanks for a great recipe

text:
This is the most delicious chili ever!  We like things hot so we add a 1/2 can (4oz) of diced jalepenos and 2 (4oz) cans of green chiles.  Delish!  Plus I put all of the ingredients into a slow cooker and cook on high for 4 hours.  Then, I take the chicken out and shred it with a fork, and return it to the crockpot for another 30-1 hr.  YUM!

Since all my cooking excursions come from AllRecipes.com I noted this recipes had many good reviews thus I tried it.  I only had two cans of cannellini beans thus the mixture came out slightly watery. I added 1 tablespoon of Quinoa which created a thicker texture while adding additional protein and whole grains. I also used a slow cooker for this recipe. The outcome was wonderful; a thick wholesome chili.  I do recommend this recipes too all that are curious to try it.

Really good! Definately cut down the peppers/cayenne. Last night, those that wanted it spicier dashed a little more cayenne pepper in their bowl. I topped with Mexican four cheese blend shredded cheese, dollop of sour cream, and chopped green onions and served with crescent rolls. YUM!!!!!

text:
I've tried many recipes from this site and I have to say this is my favorite and I get lots of compliments on it and requests for the recipe.  The changes I make are to use half the chicken broth (I use homemade), occasionally less jalapeno peppers and/or cayenne (depending on who's joining us and their tolerance for heat), and I add chopped celery.  This is pretty easy and quick and so very delicious!  I haven't made regular chili since discovering this recipe a few years ago.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have to give this 4 stars because I followed some of the reviews over the original recipe. I pureed 1 can of navy beans and 1 can of great northern beans to make a thicker base, and tossed in the other (drained but whole) can of great northern beans. I used 1 can of fat free broth and a can of low-fat cream of chicken soup. I used the whole 4 oz. of chiles but probably only about 4 jalapenos and some juice. I also cut back on the cayenne. Next time I'll use a little more, because it could have used a little more kick. I used a can of corn and tossed in a potato. I know that makes it less chili-ish, but I liked the veggies. I followed a reviewer's suggestion to use the crock pot and shredded (not too finely) the chicken about 4 hours in. We'll definitely make this one again with a little more seasoning. Thanks!

text:
I have made this several times and it's my "go to" chili recipe now.  I leave out the onions because we don't like them and to make it healthier, I leave out the oil and cheese entirely.  I used 2 cups of chicken broth to thicken it up and it's perfect every time.  Last time I even left out garlic (current pregnancy aversion) and it was still awesome.

Display Name:
RebeccaC

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3054.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an outstanding recipe.  I had some cooked shredded chicken and some raw boneless breasts, so I cooked them first in the pot where I made the chili, adding some cumin, garlic powder and chili powder.  Then I took out the chicken and followed the recipe.  The modifications I made were to reduce the amount of cayenne and to add just a tiny pinch of cinnamon.  I used half of a fresh jalapeno and a can of mild chiles.  This made it spicy but not too hot.  I cooked the chili much longer than the recipe directed-probably close to an hour which made the flavors much deeper.  I also omitted the cheese, preferring to add it afterward to my individual portions.  Big yum!!!  Even my 9 year old son, who can be kind of picky, really liked it.

text:
WOW!Great recipe for chilly winter nights!    I did make some changes, based solely on what I had on hand in the kitchen.  I added about 1/4 cup fresh chopped cilantro--this added a great flavor.  I didn't have cayenne pepper, so I used white pepper instead.  Also, I picked up a can of jalapeno peppers instead of green chiles by mistake, so I added about 1/2 of the can.  It was plenty hot enough and I LOVE spicy food!  I will try making it per the original recipe next time (when I shop for the correct ingredients)!  In the meantime, this was still a GREAT recipe and I will make it again--I highly recommend adding the fresh cilantro---tastes amazing!

text:
This recipe is a fall/winter staple at our house! It's usually the first thing I make when the weather starts to turn cold. I do make a few modifications, though: I use jarred jalapenos and no green chiles, I use a two cans of white beans and one can of black beans, and I serve cheese as a garnish instead of mixing it in. My husband and I prefer this recipe over traditional beef chili!

city:

region:

text:
This recipie was a fantastic base to start from! I only changed a couple small things though. My husband isn't really into spicy, so I omitted the jalepenos. The green chilis and cayenne added just the right kick for us. Also, as per some previous suggestions, I blended one of the cans of beans before adding, and added the others bean water and all for a more thicker chili. It worked out great. I let each person decide how much cheese they wanted to add to their taste rather than mix it all in, and this worked out to everyone's advantage.  I love the flavor, it reminds me of a great cheen chili sauce at my favorite local mexican restuarant. I will be making this again soon, per my husband's request. So I know this was a hit!

text:
We made it good.   I make very many moderations.   1. Used 1 can navy beans, 1 can kidney beans. Took 1/2 of each can and blended it up to thicken the chili.   2. Used 2 cans of green chilis.   3. Used one can of chicken broth (if not less)  4. Added hotsauce/lime/lemon juice mixture to make it tasty. It was very very bland before we did this.   5. Increased all spices.   6. Used only 1 shredded chicken  Topped with Cheese, and ate with our cornbread. I loved it! Very healthy!

text:
this is really great! i did make some changes as suggested...i pureed one can of beans for a thicker consistency and used maybe a cup or so of broth. i used a 7 oz can of green chiles, 2 oz of jalapeno, 2 stalks of celery, and 1/2 teaspoon of cayenne. this stilled turned out spicy, but not too much to handle. i didn't have fresh garlic, so i used a teaspoon of garlic powder. i really love cheese, so i added 2 cups of monterey jack. mmmmhh! i think this recipe makes a little more than 4 servings...maybe closer to 6 or 8 depending on how much you eat i guess! great recipe that can easily be modified to fit your tastes!

None
text:
Fabulous Tasting! The only change I made was instead of using the full can of jalapenos, I just used the all the "jalapeno juice" in the can by draining it and none of the actual peppers, this gave it the pepper flavor and a bit of an edge that mellowed when we had it the next day. I used 4 cooked and shredded chicken breasts that I had seasoned with salt, pepper, poultry seasoning, bay leaf (remove after baking), 1/2 cup water and baked in baking pan covered tight with foil @ 375 for approx. 50 min.  Let cool 30 minutes prior to shredding.  Twice as good the next day!!!

text:
This was delicious.  Don't expect it to be thick like chili, it's more of a soup, but it has a great flavor.  We did a few things differently:  We cooked everything in one pot, starting with cubing the raw chicken and sauteeing it.  We didn't have any jalapenos, so we left those out.  We used 1 tsp of ground cumin instead of 2.  With the tsp of cayenne, it was plenty spicy without the jalapenos.  We'll definitely have this again.

text:
This was a good recipe but I can't give it 5 stars because I'm trying to recreate a white chicken chili that was made by a friend and this wasn't quite as good.  Not a bad substitute, though.  I used a bag of dried beans instead of canned.  I quick soaked them (boil for 2 minutes, let sit for an hour, drain), dumped them into a crock pot with the broth, seasonings, 2 cans of chili's, and a can of corn.  Toward the end of cooking I threw in the cooked chicken.  A pretty good version and I'll probably be making it again but I'm still hunting for the secret that made my friend's chicken chili so good.

text:
Awesome recipe! I would've preferred a little less spice . . . maybe two cans green chiles instead of using the one can of jalapenos or just decrease the amount of cayenne pepper. My husband said he would've liked it better if it was a little thicker. I had drained the beans, so maybe if I just would have used some or all of the liquid it would have thickened it up. I served with a dollop of sour cream. Oh, and instead of using cooked chicken, I just opened up two 12.5 oz cans of chunk chicken and added to soup. Very easy and flavorful.
I made this again using 2 cans diced chiles which tamed the heat down a little. Also pureed one can of beans to thicken it up. And started with 1/2 tsp cayenne and increased to taste. Much better!!!

I make this "exactly" as stated -- EXCEPT I had to decrease the amount of jalapeno peppers (I use 1 TBS) and the cayenne to 1/2 tsp.  While I love spicy food, it doesn't seem to love me these days.  These minor modifications have served me well as I've won over several beef-only chili fans.  One even sheepishly called for the recipe when her husband found out she liked it.  He'd been bugging her for years to try something different.  This chili comes together quickly--it's in regular rotation at our house.

text:
Whew! this was spicy!!! I like spicy stuff, but even I had a coughing fit during dinner!! It was my fault though.. I couldn't find a 4oz can of jalepenos, so I bought sliced ones, and guessed on the 4oz part. I had a scale to weigh them on, but they musta been spicier than canned, plus I chopped them up myself, so I think that brought out the HOT! I wound up putting a dollop of sour cream on top, and then kinda mixed it up in my bowl to tame the taste a bit.. I put a good bit of sour cream in the rest of the chili, and added water and more chicken broth to bring it down too.. Hopefully my hubby will like it, daughter thought it was too spicy (she is 6.)  but she still liked it..

Thanks for the recipe, I will be making this again, minus so many jalepenos!!

text:
Very tasty! I've never made white chili before, and this is definitely a keeper. Smelled very good! My only deviations were adding a little fresh cilantro, and a 7oz can of chilies because that's all I had. It wasn't too spicy at all. I found another way to make it thicker, if you have time...just let it simmer an hour or two. Even though I added all the liquids and didn't puree the beans, it ended up nice and thick! It also wasn't as spicy at that point too as it was after 30 minutes...I guess because the beans broke down more.

text:
Because of all the fog and rainy yuck we've been having, I spontaneously decided chili would be a good idea tonight. I cooked the recipe and then saw that it was thin  (I think it's supposed to be that way), but the hubbie likes thicker chili, so I added 2 tablespoons each of cornstarch and flour, and two extra cans of beans (we wanted a lot to freeze for lunches at work). With those changes, and salt and pepper to taste, it was a pretty good recipe! We'll be making it again this winter I'm sure!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an easy five star recipe.  The ingredients are easy to find and the soup is easy to assemble.  I did not have diced jalapeno peppers or chopped green chili peppers so I diced a green pepper to retain the green color and added a can of Rot*el tomatoes and diced jalapeno peppers.  The red of the tomatoes combined with the green pepper provides a very festive look.  Wishing to keep the white chili color, I drained the canned Rot*el.  Prepared this way, the hot intensity was absolutely perfect; spicy and tasty, but not overwhelming.  The next time I prepare this soup I will prepare it as written and compare.  One way or the other, I have no doubt that this recipe is a winner.

text:
Excellent!  I did omit the cheese (so some might say I'm not reviewing the same recipe), but I felt I really didn't need the fat ... and the chili was great without.  I also omitted the cayenne (because I didn't have any) and threw in some chipolte chili powder ('bout a tablespoon).  MY chili came out VERY spicy....and good.  I also used rather large chunks of browned, boneless chicken breast.  Yum!!

text:
This recipe was a hit. I used black eyed peas with bacon instead of white beans. I didn't have any fresh garlic so I used dehydrated minced garlic along with garlic salt, pepper, and chicken bouillon granules to taste. I forgot to add the cheese, but it was still good. Was more like thick soup. The chili did not have a lingering hot taste. Don't leave anything out. Along with this chili, I served rice and crackers. I will definitely make this recipe again. Thanks!

text:
This was very good. I agree with those who claim it is more like soup than chili. In an effort to thicken it up, I pureed one can of beans and added 1 T cornstarch. I think it contains too much broth to actually be "chili," but it's still very good. 

Because I don't like very spicy foods and I have two young kids to please, I omitted the jalapenos and used just a dash of cayenne.  I also added about 3/4 c. frozen corn.
Very tasty, excellent for a chilly night.

text:
Excellent.  My husband loved this and has asked for it again.  I did what some of the others before me have done.  I used 1 can of chicken broth and one can of cream of chicken.  I used mild green chilis and only added 2 oz. of jalepenos.  And 1/4 teaspoon of red pepper.  It was plenty hot for me but easily cooled with a little mexi cheese mix and sour cream.  My husband could have had all the jalepenos added.  I always go easy with red pepper.  Its potent stuff.  This is a keeper.  Made it for friends and they loved it!!

text:
I love this recipe.  We now use it once a month in our Wednesday night church soup night.  It is similar to the white chicken chili you get at Ruby Tuesdays.  I just throw in the raw chicken with the soup,cook a while and shred. It takes a little longer than 15 minutes, but it is very simple and you can throw this together in minutes.  Also works in the crockpot. when you have leftovers and have already eaten it few times, you can use it another way.., it thickens in the fridge and it can be a great filling for burritos.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this two times and the 2nd time I made some adjustments and it was OUT OF THIS WORLD GOOD!!!

I used dark meat instead of chicken breast & used some of the water I boiled the chicken in for half of the chicken broth required and the other half store-bought. Dark meat is much more flavorful. 

As is, the recipe is HOT (too HOT even for me who loves hot foods) so cut back on the jalapenos and chillies. If yours turns out spicy, add a little milk at the end (it will not affect the flavor, just the spiciness) and add more cheese. Sour cream and plain yogurt will also help.

We enjoyed ours with crispy oven-baked garlic bread....wow so good!!!

text:
Absolutely delicious! I had white chili once, years ago and have been looking for a recipe ever since. I took the advice of a few other reviewers and pureed one can of beans and added cornstarch to thicken it up a bit. I left out the jalepenos (I like spice, but not too much!) I also added a little salt and used a bag of "mexican" cheese mixture (cheddar, aseago, monterey). Even my VERY picky 13-year-old daughter loves it! I made cornbread to go with it for dinner. Thanks, Cathy!

This chili is great! A little hot(spicy) but excellent. The only reason I don't give it 5 stars is because it is a little watery. I take some of the beans and puree them to thicken the chili. If it needs more thickening then I will use some corn starch mixed with some of the liquid and then add it back in to the chili.

text:
This is a REALLY great recipe. I will be making this again this winter for sure.  My husband and I love spicy food so I follows the recipe exact.  As another reviewer said, I wasn't sure if I was supposed to drain the beans or not so I just dumped the cans in, liquid and all. I think it made it a little thinner than I like my chili so I just mixed 2 Tbs of Wondra with a 1/4 cup milk, tempered it and added it to the chili to thicken. AWESOME! Highly recommended for spicy chili lovers who want something a little different than regular chili.

Display Name:
SandyPaws

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/46957.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, after many failed recipes for a white chicken chili/soup,  THIS is it :)  I read all of the reviewers comments and made some *slight* adjustments.  Since many commented that it was spicy, I tried to tone it down a few notches by 1/2 tsp of chyenne pepper, used approx 6 slices of nacho style jalepeno, diced, along w/ the  1 can of green chili peppers.  It was still very spicy/hot  but  just enuf for my taste :)   I thought the recipe was a little thin, as I think of chili as being chunky....So I  pureed one can on the beans( Great Northern), and then using my stick blender I gave the entire pot a few pulses, to thicken up the "soup". I also cooked it on a low simmer for 1 hour, again, to thicken up... I ended up w/ a hearty soup texture, which was perfect :)  I also  added a big dollop of sour cream which offset the spiciness perfectly ...
Review:

5

text:
Although I had to improvise this came out great! I didnt have a can of chopped green chilies so I used a can of green chili enchilada sauce and I sauted fresh chopped chicken breast with onions and garlic before adding any other ingredients. I brought it to a hard boil about 5 minutes before simmering in order to get the beans to come apart some and thicken it up. Serving sliced pickled jalapenos on the side satisfied my fiery friends. I will make it again!
